사냥반복하는 게임

스토리가 있기는데 일방향 진행이라 선택지가 따로 없어서 진행하며 어차피 보스전 나오겠구나.. 하며 예상이됨.
생각을 하게만드는 책 문구들도 있었고 의미심장한 대사들도 있어 스토리와 주인공(나)에 대해서 유추해가는 재미도 있었지만
스토리 진행 방식의 자유도가 없어 텍스트 - 전투 형식의 뻔한 진행 때문에 지루해져 손을 놓게 되었습니다.

특징이라고 할 만한 것은 무한파밍, 스텟활용을 통한 컨셉플 가능성, 직업에 따른 제한성이 없음.. 정도네요.

번역은 없지만 비교적 이해하기 쉬운 어휘로 구성되어 있어서 스토리 이해와 플레이에는 큰 어려움 없었습니다.
진행 방식을 제외하곤 게임은 그래픽이 좋아야한다는 고정관념을 깨는 재미가 있었으므로 추천을 드립니다.

37848812.review:
I had picked up SanctuaryRPG during a Steam sale a few years back. To be real: It was less than a dollar and I was feeling frisky. But after 70+ hours of playing this game, my thought is that the sale price is an insane steal. For the hours of entertainment and enjoyment that I've received from this game, I think the full price tag is worth it and I feel almost guilty for paying so little for a game I love so much. But hey, if you see it for 90% off (like it is RIGHT NOW... at least at the time of writing this) I fully recommend picking it up. That's value.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

SanctuaryRPG is a text-based roguelike RPG where you choose from six different classes (each with their own strengths and weaknesses) and grind your way to gain levels and find gear. The premise itself is standard, but there is enough depth to the ways one can create their own character builds that make each new game exciting. 

There are four game modes: Classic (permadeath), Softcore (respawns), Lunatic (go fuck yourself), and Survival which is unlocked through beating the game on the other modes. Most of my experience is playing on Classic, though, I had the unfortunate idea to try playing on Lunatic mode and well… this game is out to kill you. There is no hand holding. You are not safe. Encounters, like most things in this game, are randomized. In the same area that you’ll find a mob that you can one-shot with ease, you will find something that will blind you and force you into a war of attrition before slaughtering you. 

That sense of unease and fear can be a lot of the fun of this game though. It sucks to die after thinking up a new build idea and finding the perfect items (which are all RNG drops) to make it work, but there’s some charm in this game that has me throwing more and more attempts at it without ever feeling like it’s pointless. The combat is easy to learn and get into so starting fresh never feels like too much of a drag. 

There are definitely some annoyances: because random is well… random, you’re prone to legendary drops that you’re forced to throw away because they have worse stats than some common sword you found at the start of the game. Crafting can sometimes feel pointless because the items you make are just as random as anything you can find from killing mobs (though it is an extra chance at loot). And the inability to hold any armor/weapons besides the ones that you are wearing can feel incredibly frustrating, though, it does make one more mindful of the gear they choose to pick up and forces the player to play and build around the items they find (which can make for some interesting characters).      

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The ASCII-style art of SanctuaryRPG is one of the features that initially stood out to me when I purchased the game and are one of many things that make the game unique. There is a lot of variation in characters, mobs, and environments that is achieved perfectly in this style and are well made. It serves to capture the setting and tone of this game which is very old-school and quirky. 

It’s definitely a matter of taste. The screenshots give a good idea of what this game looks like (though, there are some very nice pieces of art that one gets to view as they progress through the story). Some people may be put off, but this game has its own niche that it fills and the ASCII-art continues that theme and charm. 

[h1]Story[/h1]

Another fun part of SanctuaryRPG is the writing and the tone and universe it is set within. There is a lot of comedy throughout the game: a lot of silly and random (like the gameplay itself) events that have you milking ghosts, stealing weapons from hobos, or eating flying pancakes. Even in the creation of your character alone you are given an elaborate randomized backstory that sets the fun and humourous tone for things to come.

That said, SanctuaryRPG isn’t devoid of a narrative and it isn’t solely lolsorandom humour (not that I minded the more lighthearted parts of the game anyway). The main plot of the game, while seemingly standard, has your character fighting through places of the world and discovering more about its lore and people.Though, there aren’t many huge plot twists that will keep you awake at night or any moments that will elicit intense emotions. 

The story gets the job done and there’s enough intrigue to keep you wanting to get to the end, though the worldbuilding is what I’d consider a stronger element than the plot itself. This game has an interesting setting that feature both dragons and low-technology weaponry alongside robots and portals. It feels like its own unique setting and while it does borrow many classic RPG tropes, it arranges them in fun ways that allows the setting to stand out on its own.

[h1]Music[/h1]

SactuaryRPG’s soundtrack composed by Rafael Langoni Smith consists of 64 chiptune-style tracks. Along with the ASCII-style art, the music helps to give the game both an old-school vibe and its own unique elements. There is a lot of variety in the soundtrack: from the soft and relaxing (Sanctuary Arp II: Title Screen) to dark and ominous (You May Be Experiencing Some Discomfort) to intense and triumphant (Sangue nos Olhos). 

There are some really great and memorable melodies in these tracks. The music often serves as another driving force to make one want to continuing playing longer. There’s a thrill in getting into a fight, hearing a particular track and just knowing that you’re fucked. This is a game soundtrack that I’d actually recommend listening to solely on its own as well!

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

+Multiple ways to play/build your character
+Easy to get into, but plenty to master
+Unique artstyle
+Comedy-focused writing (which can be good or bad depending on one’s taste, but I’m personally found it entertaining)
+Decent world-building that gives the setting and world intrigue
+Melodic chiptune-style music

+/-RNG adds an element of surprise, but also annoyance
+/-Standard plot that gets the job done, but could have been expanded further (though, I admit that I enjoyed the game regardless of the story)

-Epic/Legendary weapons mean very little since their stats are randomized and often unuseful
-Crafting as well as some other features (such as the Temple or Library) can feel pointless since the same things can be achieved through grinding

36348491.review:
[h1]8.8/10[/h1]
Esse jogo não pareceu muita coisa no começo, mas depois de morrer e passar raiva algumas vezes eu pude sentir o brilho por trás do grande RPG que é o SanctuaryRPG.

-Análise geral
Se você nunca jogou algum jogo que não tem gráfico (como foi o meu caso), provavelmente a primeira impressão dentro do jogo é de limitação. Não parece ter muita coisa pra fazer além de apertar botões repetidamente. As batalhas são por turnos, mas diferente de Final Fantasy ou Breath of Fire, por exemplo, no SanctuaryRPG a tela só atualiza com os novos números de HP, MP, etc. A história parece ser mais do mesmo de sempre, sobre um artefato e um sujeito muito poderoso que você tem que matar por algum motivo, e quando você menos percebe já está numa missão secundária, sendo que a principal nem foi tão envolvente nem nada. Daí você morre (no modo clássico, se você morrer acaba a partida e tem que começar outra do zero) e começa de novo, com o mesmo artefato, o mesmo vilão, a mesma introdução, as mesmas batalhas que parecem meio monótonas. Essas são as primeiras impressões dentro do jogo. Na terceira ou quarta vez eu consegui um item muito bom e tinha ficado forte o suficiente pra prosseguir na história, mas logo depois morri, e não pelo jogo ser monótono, mas por eu não ter pensado durante a batalha. Comecei outra partida e entendi como funcionam os combos nas batalhas. Percebi que cada inimigo tem uma particularidade, um ponto fraco e um forte, e comecei a explorar cada vez mais as opções dentro do jogo. Foi aí que percebi que o jogo tem um sistema legal de comércio [spoiler] (não vou dar spoiler não vou dar spoiler mas o sistema de comprar cerveja quando estiver barata e vender quando a taverna tá bem cheia aumenta o brilho do jogo) [/spoiler], um sistema de arena (tem um coliseu com ranks), um sistema de craftar itens, e alguns sistemas interno que só jogando pra ver, mas que acabam dando pluralidade dentro do jogo. Aí, quando você começa a explorar essas coisas, fica fácil perceber a importância dos itens certos, e quando você vê morreu de novo, e começa de novo, avançando na história e ficando sempre com medo de perder o seu personagem level 35 que levou tanto tempo pra ficar fortinho. 
Eu tô numa situação agora que as batalhas são sempre pensadas, e a opção de fugir da luta, que eu raramente uso em RPGs, se faz muito útil quando eu acho que vou morrer. Além das batalhas, digo que a história é legal, os personagens são bacanas, e os criadores do jogo têm o mérito de serem bem criativos em vários pontos.

-Gráficos:
8/10. Levando em conta que é um gráfico composto só por caracteres ASCII, as imagens do jogo (esqueletos, NPCs, cenários, masmorras, itens) são bem feitos. As telas podem ser confusas no começo mas depois que você imerge no game você esquece que tá jogando um jogo sem gráfico, sério mesmo.

-Som:
8.5/10. Novamente, levando em conta que SanctuaryRPG se inspira em jogos antigos, sua trilha sonora é compatível com esse estilo, mas é bem trabalhada, não tem do que se falar mal.

-Jogabilidade:
8.5/10. Depois que você imerge no jogo as coisas ficam fáceis. Movimentar-se no jogo fica fácil, e como tudo é por teclas, com o tempo vai ficando tudo mais rápido. Embora no começo seja fácil ficar perdido e achar tudo complexo, os comandos são simples e intuitivos.

-Durabilidade:
9/10. Não terminei o jogo ainda (PORQUE EU NÃO PARO DE MORRER, DROGA), mas até onde joguei me diverti bastante. Dentro do jogo há um aviso de que depois de terminar o jogo no modo clássico, um novo modo é liberado, além de alguns sets de itens novos (seja lá o que isso seja). Eu joguei até agora só de Ranger e Bárbaro, mas são 6 ou 7 classes diferentes entre si não só nas suas características mas no modo de jogo. Tem algumas coisas no jogo que sugerem desafios pra depois do jogo ter sido finalizado (na arena há uma opção que avisa ser só para jogadores experientes). Acho que mesmo depois que o jogo acaba, nunca vai ser chato revisitar o game por causa do seu estilo que é totalmente diferente dos outros da biblioteca.

-Desafio:
10/10. O dinheiro e os itens não são tão fáceis dentro do jogo. Itens não são guardáveis. Às vezes você escolhe um item errado e só percebe depois de ter se desfeito do anterior, o que te obriga a ficar sempre ligado nas coisas relacionadas aos bens e ao dinheiro. Isso sem falar na morte permanente. É frustrante, mas é muito legal. Você pode perder uma partida de várias horas numa bobeira. A cautela, depois de um tempo, passa a ser um instrumento fundamental em toda caverna, em todo lugar, em todo evento que você encontra pelo mundo. Não só pelo medo de perder tudo, mas tem batalhas que são muito desafiadoras, que você tem que usar a cabeça de verdade. Com o tempo a sua gama de opções de ataques e movimentos na luta aumentam, e você é obrigado a usar alguma estratégia (com inimigos à altura, claro). No meu caso, eu passei a analisar como são os monstros, quais seus ataques, seus padrões, pra evitar riscos. E, sempre, na pior das hipóteses, correr da luta pode ser a melhor das opções.

-Custo/Benefício:
10/10. Comprei numa promoção, e pelo tanto que me diverti jogando isso (aqui marca 7 horas de jogo mas eu joguei talvez o dobro disso offline) já valeu. Sério, se estiver numa boa promoção e você está indeciso, pode comprar.

CONCLUSÃO:
É um jogo bem diferente dos demais. Parece complicado, parece monótono, mas depois de se familiarizar com o jogo é fácil perder algumas horas nele. Os elementos de RPG em SanctuaryRPG são bem clássicos, e pra quem gosta de jogos do gênero que se passam em turnos, é um prato cheio, recomendo.

33887341.review: SanctuaryRPG is a strange game. Strange in tone: the game's strange sense of humor and obsession with potatoes will either leave you laughing or weirded out. Strange in gameplay: the game combines elements from roguelikes (randomized content, ASCII graphics, dying erases your save file), western and eastern RPGs (leveling up, turn based combat), and fighting games (combos and positioning in battle). Add to that a stellar chiptune soundtrack and you have a game that's not for everyone, but if it sounds to your tastes, you should go ahead with it. If you're on the fence, wait for a sale: the game is often 90% off, a steal.

33864746.review:
Great timewaster of a game. I'm reviewing now since I've finished the game as a Huskian Barbarian.

So let me just say straight out that the soundtrack to this game is overall one of the best I've heard. Especially one of the themes that plays for boss fights. 

Now there's a tutorial for this game if you want to turn it on when you start, but honestly I didn't really understand the mechanics of this game for a long time. Because of that issue, I wound up losing god knows how many characters to that problem. The time it takes to learn the mechanics of the game is a real drawback, and hope something can be done to better address the importance of mechanics like Repositioning. At least starting new characters gets really quick, and hardly takes much time to reach where you left off.

Once you get a handle on the game's mechanics in battle and out, its pretty fun, and fast paced.

So is the story pretty good too? Yes, its cool. Cool is the simplest descriptor I can give you. I enjoyed the odd blend of science and fantasy within the game's lore. The humor is just as strange and sometimes the jokes could make me bust out laughing, especially the beginning game's text describing the life your character has led before the start. I only wish the ending was a tad stronger, or there were more opportunities to learn more of the lore and history of the world you're living inside of.

If you got the patience to stick through many rough beginnings, then you'll be rewarded with a great title that will have you telling yourself, "Just one more fight!" or "That next armor will be the one I need!"

32328937.review:
All good (but addicting)

This is an edit to my earlier brief review.  I just defeated the Matron, but it appears that there is much more content ahead.  Who knows, maybe my barbarian will get to level 300.  For me, much of the attraction of this turn-based game is in the rich diversity of the weapons, armor, shields, charms.  Each item boosts 2 of 5 attributes (vitality, strength, intelligence, dexterity, or wisdom.)  Items have different levels of rarity.  They can have special prefixes giving boosts. Finding, buying or crafting these items is great fun, and as a character advances, the loot gets stronger.  Other aspects of the game (music, humor, depth) come together.  I will confess that while I play the game on Classic difficulty, I will occassionally go to the Steam data file on my computer and make a copy of the save files to a folder.  I understand that this is frowned upon by part of the gaming community, but I enjoy the game more having the backup.  My point here is that the game can be played in whatever fashion is most enjoyable to you.

I grew up playing text-based games like this when the Commodore 64 was "all the rage" and what not, like the old person I am, so this game really clicks with me.

The combat is challenging if you don't know the rules (which is quite well done, gotta say), though if you feel like spending hours over-leveling like me then you can feel free to swat skeletons around all you please. Even so, there are many battles where just being over-leveled isn't going to help you and you really need to slow down and focus. I love that the battling isn't all mindless tapping after a certain point; there's always that one enemy that can really kick your groin in.

"...it's really pleasing to see a game (such as SancturaryRPG Black Edition of course!) as originally written for it's time while being such a lolloping heckle from the past."
-Boniface, 5 star review

Explosive and hilarioius. This game has the humour of One Punch Man and game play like One Piece the anime. It make a me ROFL for 16 hours.

The game mechanics are well made, it feels like there are advanced options if you want to be aware of (and take advantage of) them - but you can also just totally smash everything, craft sweet items, ignore the equally funny character perks, and merily hack and slash until you die. Which you must. You, must die.

Die, read the redicuous intro to your new life and enjoy the Classic mode of rougue like games. And then I kept reviewing....

In the early 2000's, I used to play WOTMUD; a text based game inspired by the 'Wheel of Time' series by Robert Jordan. Yes I PlAyeD it for many a year in all it's complexities, for it's amazing descriptions of each room you entered, and for its' breathtakingly large, namely community made, map.

Earlier than this was the early 90's when I played dungeon based text games, which are really terrifying to a five year old on the cusp of literacy, and far too linear to generate child lolz. In the general evolution of games and what can be called pleasurable, it's really pleasing to see a game (such as SancturaryRPG Black Edition of course!) as originally written for it's time while being such a lolloping heckle from the past.

31878451.review:
Quel est ce monde diabolique tout droit sorti du moyen-âge, et pourquoi ces entités sont-elles imbriquées de chiffres et de lettres ?
Il est clair que c'est un renouveau dans le monde du RPG, car effectivement, vous êtes affublé d'un patronyme d'un genre nouveau : Le chevalier ASCII.

Cette planète-donjon asciienne vous retiendra un certain temps puisqu'une malédiction sans nom, dévaste cet endroit.

Autrefois reposait dans un roc une épée ascienne digne d'excalibur, qui pouvait déchirer le voile de l'espace-temps. 
Celle-ci en effet  bien gardée, jusqu'à l'arrivée d'une matrone dissidente.

La matrone commenca a vouloir lancer des sorts ascii, mais un magicien non-moins asciien lui-aussi, nommé cyrus, réussi temporairement à enfermer la matronne dans un cristal.

Dorénavant trop puissante, cette dernière réussi à s'échapper en invoquant le pouvoir ancestral du proto-asciien et recommenca à ternir ce monde.
Et l'histoire s'enchaîne donc avec notre dévoué cyrus et ses compagnons, équipés de leurs baluchons et de leur besaces magiques, las de l'action néfaste de la matronne, qui lutteront contre l'oppresseur asciien à l'aide d'un arsenal RPG.

La main remplace la souris, l'ascci remplace remplace le c++, l'imagination remplace l'apparence, "le Rôleplay" est décidément efficace.

Brandis ton épée chevalier et rappelle à ton compagnon cyrus la certaine faiblesse ascienne subie qui n'aura plus lieu d'être, car ton culte est maintenant entièrement dévoué à l'ascii, que tu le veuilles ou non.

Original, RPG, Gameplay basique old-school, du bonheur et de l'ascii .

31816108.review:
Key provided free via Black Shell Media.

There is a certain amount of affection I have for SanctuaryRPG.  Back in 2014 a young and naive boy was creating slighty cringy videos on a youtube channel that had but a few watchers.  Most people saw just another face in the crowd, another young lad attempting to reach fame and fortune through an overly saturated market.  Black Shell Games did not.  They saw an entertainer trying to be the cause of laughter and discussion but was lost in a sea of those exactly like he.  They took pity on this young soul and gifted him a copy of their newest game: SanctuaryRPG.

Three years later, they still remembered him and his weird videos (and disgusting goatee) and sent him a copy of their updated title, now on steam.

As you can probably tell, SRPG takes me far back into the areas of my life that I try to repress.  I remember the excitement of being approached by a developer about sharing their game with my small audience.  Words cannot describe the joy I found from that simple tweet so long ago.

The amount of bias I have for the game does not subtract from the absolute comedy and D&D like gameplay that the game provides.  SRPG is a exceptional example of early text-based adventure games and even surpases many of its predecessors in innovation.  Simple dungeon-crawler gameplay allows for more time spent of the development of the ASCII graphics, which look amazing.  Never has 1s and 0s looked so good.

The only negative thing I can say about the game is the monotony that is the combat.  I believe this to be a fault of the style rather than the execution.  As everything is text-based there is not much room for improvment or innovation when all you can do is select 1, 2, 3, or 4.  Even with special abilities and status effects, there really isn't anything good about the combat and I can only play for a few minutes at a time before boredom overtakes me and I desire something else.

In short, SanctuaryRPG is a perfect example of the bygone era of the text-based genre.  The story, music, and RPG components more than make up for any failure and fault of the combat system.  Casual and hardcore gamers have much to find and many hours to be lost in this beautiful dungeon crawler.
Pick it up now or on sale, either way is worth your time.
Thanks!

31370059.review:
SanctuaryRPG is a mess and I'd had enough after playing for 3+ hours.  They should've called this game “1,2,3,3 simulator”.

     Here's the game in a nutshell.  Start game by selecting classic (Permadeath) or Softcore (Non-perma death).  Then you'll pick a character type.  You'll do some tutorial stuff but by 20-30 minutes in you'll have everything available to you.  The game is essentially divided into 2 portions, dungeons (grinding) and town (farming).  In dungeons, you'll fight monsters, bosses, run into events, and occasionally get some random items.  In town, you can go to a bunch of different shops, craft items, run your tavern, and fight in a colosseum.

     I don't really have a lot of positive things to say about this game.  Graphics and music are both fine, that's it.  If you're into games where all you do is farm/grind, then this is the game for you.  If you can't stand non-stop farming/grinding because you like games that are actually fun and challenging, you should strongly consider never playing this game.  There's a good game in here somewhere, but it's almost as if every design decision was chosen based on maximizing how obnoxious it could be.  I could go on for a long time on the bad stuff, but I'll try to hit the main things.

     1.  There's no actual dungeon crawling/exploring in this game (at least there's none in ACT 1).  Rather than go through dungeons or explore, the game gives you a list of areas you can go to along with the recommended level for that area.  You simply press that button “1”, or “2” or “3” and hit enter.  Then  1 of 3 things will pop up:  A. You'll fight an enemy or a boss.  B. An event will occur.  Events just tell you something happening and then you make one of two (sometimes four) choices.  If you choose to pick an option that has you participate in the event, then something good or bad will happen completely at random.  C.  The last thing that happens is you'll find some random item that you don't give a crap about or you'll unlock a mercenary who acts as a passive damage buff in combat.  So 50% of the game devolves down to you pressing 2, fighting an enemy, pressing 2, fighting an enemy, pressing 2, finding an item, pressing 2, fighting an enemy, pressing 2, EVENT!  You find a box: “A” to open box or “B” to leave..... press A, “The box explodes, you're left with one hp”.  Heal up, press 2, fighting an enemy, press 2, fighting an enemy, game now unlocks boss area.  Press 3 to fight boss, beat boss, new area opens up.  Press 3 to go to new area, fight enemy, press 3, find an item, press 3 fight an enemy......... This is the game.  If you found that obnoxious to read, just wait until you play it.  It never stops until your character dies, you beat the game, you kill yourself, or you decide you'd rather go play something interesting.

     2.  The other 50% of the game will be spent in the town farming items/gold.  You'll get a crap ton of craftable material.  You'll go to the blacksmith and give him your material and he'll make you a weapon completely at random.  If it's better, press “E” to equip, if it's not, press “S” to salvage it for parts.  There's no inventory system, you either equip it or get rid of it.  You can go to your own base and dig to randomly find items or dig for iron which will allow you to craft a random piece of equipment once you have 100 iron.  You can also craft armor, charms, and other things in your base.  You'll play a terrible minigame every single time you want to craft an item at your base.  How good the item will be is mostly random, especially since the game always picks the 2 character stats it will increase at random.  You can also run a tavern, which will allow you buy beer to sell to customers and randomly get gifts (equipment or craftable materials usually).  Even selling beer to customers isn't fun.  There's a set number of customers, a set price for buying beer, and a set price for selling beer.  If the price for selling is higher, buy beer and sell it until you run out of customers.  I've never seen the price of buying beer higher than the selling price, so the entire tavern is just another farming items/gold system.  The town can take a while to go through when you have a bunch of craftable material.  Then when 95% of the stuff you craft turns out to be crap, you get more craftable material from salvaging it, so you then craft more crap............  It gets old really quickly.

     3.  The last thing I'll touch on is the actual fighting.  It seems like it should be quick and easy, but it isn't.  It's needlessly complex and if you actually take your time while fighting, the game would take a long, long, long time to beat.  There are way too many status/damage inflicting things going on during battles, and they occur all over the screen.  You have to pay attention to enemy distance, enemy prefix abilities, status effects on enemies, status effects on you, then you have to look out for the ensnare status effect which shows up at a different spot from the other status effects.  Bosses have bars that fill up for special attacks, you have bars that fill up for things.  Sometimes quick time events pop up after you/enemy take actions, so you need to be on the lookout for these too.  Then there're your choices for actions, these change as you take certain actions, so you'll have to look at what these do each and every time.  Probably the dumbest thing though is that the game gives you the option to press “?” to see a list of what all the different status effects do, but doing this actually takes up your turn during combat and allows the enemy to attack you.  What idiot decided it was a good idea to penalize the player for looking at what a status effect does?  Most of this is irrelevant though.  You see, during fights against normal enemies, all you need to do is press this combination over and over again until you win, “1,2,3,3”.  So that's all you'll do over and over and over and over and over every single fight.  You do have to watch your hp on occasion.  If you see it go down below 40%, press 4 to heal, then go back to pressing 1,2,3,3 over and over again.  This makes a large portion of the game brainless and pointless, as you'll autopilot through battle after battle after battle.  The only time you really need to pay attention to what's happening is during boss fights.  But even then you can just sort of brainlessly chug along looking solely for key words or keeping an eye on your hp, that's how I beat the final boss for ACT I.

     I could go on about how horrible this game is but I'll stop.  It really comes down to this.  If you like braindead games where you spend 95+% of your time mindlessly grinding/farming nonstop, then get this game, because it will make you jizz in your pants.  If you want to play something that will challenge you, requires skill, and will actually activate some areas of your brain, then never play this.

31349902.review:
This is one of my favorite games for plenty of reasons. In short, the dialog is entertaining, music is amazing, combat is repetative but in a fun and replayable way. If you are a moba player you espeically understand what I mean by that.

In long.

+Combat
Face value you have limited options, which isn't neccessarily a bad thing, but if you take the time to read up on the items and the types of enemies you encounter you can easily expand upon the play near limitlessly. Also if you are spam pressing away at 123412341234 ult then you would see that there are times that you gain special leverage over enemies. Usually a grapple or the description would read a very blunt tell of what they way do next. Which has saved my character from the meat grinder at least once every play of it.

+Music
This is a personal taste but really the music is fitting to the point where you won't want to turn it down to youtube a playlist while you play. Obviously depending on how long your sitting is for this would change as even the most blessed works get tuned out.

+Visual
There are plenty of ways to paint a games graphics. With the ASCII text being the shapes that detail the picture it is able to really tell more about the scene than it should. Its funy how I am more immersed and pleased with these than most realistic looking games. I feel as though the visual design for this game draws me closer to it than if it were just pictures like visual novels or even an animated out sprite battle.

This review, like most is based upon my experience and personal feelings about the game. It is possible that views change from person to person but I heavily reccomend trying this title out.

SanctuaryRPG is an old school, menu driven, turn based RPG.  With it’s ASCII graphics and chiptune soundtrack this game feels like it was released sometime between Zork and Ultima. While the simple look and chiptune soundtrack may make players think that there’s not much to this title, that couldn’t be further from the truth. The sheer number of story quests, side missions, and loot, combined with a vast variety of character possibilities there is a lot of complexity hidden beneath the simple design. 

I would recommend that you definitely buy this game (in a sale). The sound is great. The writing is funny and well done. The graphics are amazing considering it’s all done in text. Black Shell Games really did an amazing job.

30621067.review:
SanctuaryRPG is a unique experience and an overall good game with some flaws.

Note: there aren't any direct spoilers, but characterizations of story elements. So if you don't want to know if the ending was good/bad or if the story was refreshing/terrible, you probably don't want to read further

Pros:
-The game's art 100% ASCII art and it looks pretty cool
-The music direction is on point; music is always thematically appropriate and pleasant
-The battle system is interesting and there is a lot you COULD do with it
-The story up until Act IV is decent
-The loot system can be entertaining
-There is depth to the stats and class system
-There is no inventory space regarding equipment, which makes loot-based decisions more important

Cons:
-Story past Act III is virtually nonexistant ("legion warriors" are repetitive and seem like placeholder bosses)
-Battle system rewards repition until boss fights, making the game feel grindy
               *That being said, when you first start out it feels interesting and fun
-The crafting system, while initially interesting, becomes very grindy once you figure it out
-The loot and crafting system drops entirely random drops, which makes trying to find "ideal loot" hard and grindy
-There is no inventory space regarding equipment, which makes equipping your character strategically difficult and wastes a lot of the variability in equipment effects

Meh
-The ending didn't feel decisive to me, but it did feel appropriate for the game
-The music, while very good, felt repetitive due to the grind (noticibly so in Act IV)
-The town NPCs all have the same dialogue througout acts, while there is clearly potential to vary that dialogue with changes in the story
-Having grinding being important to the gameplay means that having an astronomical amount of funny names becomes critical
-The humor is hit or miss; the game has its own references [namely to potatoes] and occasionally makes use of nonsequitor jokes. (I personally enjoyed it but can completely understand why others would not)

Overall, I felt like the pros were good enough to outshine the cons. This is especially true if you're new to the game. I didn't really feel the cons of the game until the last couple of hours.

30230404.review:
SanctuaryRPG caught me completely by surprise. I love older RPG's such as Nethack, Wizardry and the like and I was expecting something akin to that. What I got was a bit different, and I'm glad I took the plunge. It is more akin in some ways to games like Oregon Trail. Acting as a sort of roguelike adventure, you create a character and are given their generated backstory. Then you hop into the world proper exploring areas, fighting monsters, and trying to improve your character enough to take on the next major challenge. There are fun mini games as part of the game mechanics such as the crafting system where you need to balance the quality, durability, and "heat" of an item as you craft them. The combat itself acts in a similar resource management fashion, having the player link skills together into combos while constantly repositioning themselves in the battle to distance themselves from heavy handed enemy "charge" attacks and make sure they are properly managing their HP and MP for when enemies do big damage.

Another thing I really like is the sense of humor. I have not put a lot of time into the game yet but already there have been lots of fun little jokes that don't take away from the overall experience and really give the game personality. The aesthetics are great (I love that there is a character creation system in a game comprised entirely of ASCII) and the music is bloody fantastic with sounds that span several eras of gaming while remaining modern and appropriate to the source material. 

These guys have crafted something really special. For the price I feel like I have already gotten my moneys worth only after about an hour of playing, and it is clear that there is far more depth to be found than that.

A very original game. The writing is both good and weird, leaving me flabbergasted at what just happened many times. The music is nothing short of excellent! Seemingly easy to grasp concepts bear far more depth than a quick glance would indicate. All in all I'd say this game is quite the.. experience.

But!

I died many times without actually getting why. SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition can be very random at times. And while the gameplay tempts you to rush encounters, since most of them can be resolved by pressing the same two or three keys over and over, doing so can quickly lead to disaster when an opponent suddenly does something unexpected. Like reducing you from full health to.. nothing.

After losing two high level characters in situations in which I had absolutely no idea what I could have done differently, my butthurt reached a point where I simply had to uninstall.

So in conclusion, I have to give a thumbs down for this one. But that's just me. If you are less of a filthy casual than me and can stomach losing hours of gameplay to hard-to-grasp mistakes and/or generally have the patience to pay attention to more or less the same screen, looking for slight differences in statuses and numbers to avoid these mistakes in the first place; go for it! The game is not very expensive. And for the price, you can get quite the amount of entertainment out of it. Just don't expect it to be overly casual.

29531959.review:
First of all, saying that saying this game is genius is a understatement is an understatement in and of itself, this game is the Hawking of game designs, it's that original and unique. It's like they put the best parts of several genres into a blender and this game is the delicious smoothie that came out. There's Rogue-like, Text-Based adventures, and Turn-based RPGs elements, and an outstanding humour as well. Also, it's all in ASCII. Yes, you read me right, and that was one of the best design decisions made by the developers, I'll get into that soon.

Several years ago, someone known as The Matron searched and found a legendary sword capable of destroying armies by itself, and with that sword, she set out to destroy the world as we know it.
But then, a hero appeared, a powerful man, a born leader, the guiding light to command us all. Cyrus, The Magnificent (Y'know, Tim, The Enchanter's little brother). After the great war that occurred after our Hero's arrival, and our victory, The Matron was sealed in an ice crystal, but after some time of peace, she broke out, escaping back into our world, and Cyrus, Disappeared…
Now you, brave hero, must stop The Matron once and for all, and rid this world of darkness.
The game's story is really clever and funny, creating a randomly generated one for each character you make, and trust me, you will have to make several before completing this game, giving you plenty of backstory to read, all of them incredibly hilarious.

The game is like a text adventure game, the screen displays several actions, and you choose one of them, but it requires a lot of strategy, as the combat is turn-based and really difficult to master. the game also has several rogue-like elements to it, perma-death and unlocks for future runs, and everyone knows that's how you get to my good side, I adore rogue-likes. But don't be fooled, this game has very little RNG to it, it is all strategy, without that you won't win the game! There's also a lot of character development and creation, you can choose a class, a race, and a weapon specialization, it's a bit complicated at first, but when you get the hang of it, you see how well done it is.

The graphics are honestly amazing for ASCII, it shows how much time the developers spent on making the enemies and the scenery, and the music and sound effects are just wonderful, it truly feels like those old games, and there's also a cover of the soundtrack in the piano, and it is lovely.
Everything is just so old-school, I love it.
And that brings me to the main selling point of this game, It looks and plays like the old MS-DOS games, but with a modern design, story and humour to it, and it feels great, this game is nothing short of genius, you've really got to commend the developers for making such a great piece of gaming art.

Overall, if you've lived in the era of the birth of gaming, you've got to play this game for the nostalgic value, and if you haven't, you also need to play this game to get an idea of how games used to be, it's just a wonderful piece of game history and art.

Read more Video Game reviews at cassus.org

29305615.review:
SanctuaryRPG is probably one of the best RPG's I've played, and this is in large part due to it's simplicity. It has complex combat mechanics like Dwarf Fortress, quality battle music of any 90's era RPG, the humor of The Hitchhiker's Guide, and the feeling of nostalgia for older games that very few "8-bit RPG roguelike mashups" can accomplish.

If I had two complaints for this game, they'd be as follows: I wish the game was available on Linux. I program enough to know that this game is written in C++, and from what I can tell, uses libraries that are available on Linux. It may not be as easy as "press button to Linux", but it'd be nice for the few fans who don't often use Windows.

My other complaint is that I wish I knew about this game sooner; this game would have made my childhood.

10/10

29279690.review:
As a millenial, I was astonished about the detailed pictures you can get out of ASCII symbols. The music is not bad either.

Those positive things said, this game does not feel good to me. As you do not see any moving sprites, it is naturally very much focussed on text and numbers, which means reading all the time (of course without voice acting). The omnipresence of stat numbers makes the combat and world exploration quite abstract and static. As this kind of technology cannot possibly win you over on a visual level, the writing could have been the means to create some kind of atmosphere. Unfortunately, the creators missed this opportunity, making an attempt on a weird surrealistic humour that did not make me laugh once (Pony Island was much cleverer in my opinion). Even worse, it destroys the immersion again and again, and you should not do that in an RPG unless you are really talented in writing self-ironic and fourth-wall-breaking scripts.

It is interesting to try out new and old concepts as alternatives to the modern mainstream, but there is a reason why ASCII-interfaces are not used anymore. Sorry - 3/10 from me.

I'll start by saying this is probably the best $0.79 i've ever spent (and also pardon my sub-par attempt at reviewing, i'm not used to this)

Combat consists of going through combo-attacks, while keeping an eye out and reacting to enemy attacks. There will be various prompts warning you of enemy attacks, so you have a turn or two to react accordingly. During combat there are also various other abilities and prompted-actions you can perform (react to an enemy attack by charging, grappling, etc.). 

Leveling is not limited to grinding enemies though, as you can study in the library, play the crafting minigame (provided you have the materials) to gain xp, as well as tending to a Bar.

Progress relies pretty heavily on your current gearing, so mining ore and collecting materials to craft items should be a priority... or you can get lucky and RNGesus will give you awesome gear.

TL:DR: Combat is turn-based, trying to brute force it will quickly lead to death. Craft or find gear to kill stuff faster and not get turned into mush. Burn all the Potatoes. Do not try to approach hobos, they hurt. Enjoy the glorious soundtrack. Do not contract dysentary.

Disclaimer: I have only made it to Act II so far, and am only level 37 (Max is 300) so far, but I [b]will[/b] say that the game is quite fun for the time being.

        [td]2/3[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]    

[b]LONG VERSION[/b]

1. Control and Gameplay : it's easy to get used to the gameplay (mostly use only ONE letter/number to do action), it's does not require high requirement pc (because the design is so simple), so far no lags/ bugs. Some skills / status are hard to remember (there are A LOT of them), but there is a tutorial book so rest assured.

2. Fun Factor : I like the catchy tunes and the game simple design, reminds me of older type of rpgs on older consoles. Because of the simple control of the game, I could do something else by playing (for example: eating my ramen). Also, there is a difficulty slider (if you want the game easier/ harder). There are a lot of choices we need to make and it AFFECTS the actual gameplay. I like it because I could make my own story as well.

3. Graphic : very cute even though it's only using simple ASCII art. Very refreshing concept and contrast to the mega popular 3D objects. No special interface for this game, though. I don't know why can't it open the steam overlays to capture images (?) Too bad there were a lot of moments to be remember.

4. Replayability Value : VERY HIGH because there are several save slots for different characters (with each different jobs), different playstyle (even though some moves are similar, just some minor changes in names/ description), different quest and difficulties (still the main quest is same for all playtrough), and also the main reason is : [spoiler]Beware of death on Classic mode-- it's permanent death for your current character, surprise you need to play a new game with new character).[/spoiler]

5. Sound : catchy tunes also I get some free piano style music dlc. Unless you want some real "music", this one will not amuse you that much.

6. Story : can't say it's good yet. So far, all of the character have same main story and it's kinda linear and "gimmicky". If you want real story (and you are not into the "make your own story" thing), this game offers not much of a complexity of a heroic story. The conversation also doesn't hold any meaning to the story.

7. Value for Full Price : to support the great indie developers out there, why not? But yaay I get it when Steam Winter Sale being hold, so got it for only 10% of full price. It's kinda pricey for full price, but still okay since I realized making this kind of game need some deep thoughts from the devs. 

Thank you for reading!

29123911.review:
Look on the bright side first, the soundtrack is great. The control scheme is neat. I like the graphic and some of the humors. I like the fact that bought this game for only 80 cent and got a full day out of it.

Okay, now to the rant. The game design is broken beyond helping.

I had a legendary dagger called "Riot" on a human wizard maxing out Dex, became a Grandmaster at level 80, and I still couldn't kill the final boss. So, I sold the legendary dagger and bought a common axe that has Umbral enchantment and slew boss with 0 point in Strength or Heavy Mastery.

How do I feel about this anticlimatic ending? I feel trolled.

1) Forget about tank builds
- This game has HP, but late-game bosses (everything from the matron onwards) kill you via % max HP bleed, doom and mana threasing.
- This game has evasion and block, but late-game bosses kill you via unavoidable, everlasting and incurable % max HP bleed, doom, and mana threasing.
- This game has heals, but ALL of them deteriorate when you use ANY of them in a boss fight. I basically had to drop half of the combo set that has heals in it in order to preserve heal power for the last one third boss gauge.
- Meanwhile, enemies grow stronger in time (you can too but your damage scaling is just way worse)

2) Forget about dps builds
- This game has combo, but your combo count resets upon heal and hitting a thorning boss costs 25% max HP to bleed stack PER HIT so it's impossible to combo. Also, nimble enemies break your combo (and in turn, your ultimate) entirely.
- This game has ultimate, but late-game bosses have immunity to your ultimate, curse or bind you every other turn (as free action, they can ensnare you in the middle of their charge, which is ridiculous).
- This game has statuses, your version inflicts % CURRENT HP, your enemy's version inflicts % MAX HP. Also, late-game bosses are immune to all statuses.

3) Forget about new game+
- This game has classes, but all classes have the same 1, 2, 3, 3 combo with little to no variations (same damage, same cost, same heal effects), the same mantras, the same specials, the same force barrier, the same time reversal, the same ultimates, etc.
- Nothing changes past first playthrough.

After that it becomes a mindless grinder with the most uninteresting and cliche story ever. Just go to the blacksmith, exchange scrap for new weapon, salvage or equip it. Get more resources. Get quest (always the same), check if there’s some new weapons for sale. Next, go to market and buy stuff for blacksmith and take quest. Go to library – read books. Get exp. Create more books with hides. Go to your camp, dig some holes. Upgrade your camp. Craft randomly generated swords, shields, armor and charms. Go to tavern, sell beer, get quest to kill some mobs. Finally go kill some mobs with the same pattern: press 1, press 2, press 3, press 3. Repeat. Sometimes you need to avoid incoming attack with repositioning, heal yourself with 4 or use special attack with R. That’s it. Repeat all the steps all the way through to the end of the game. Mindless. User reviews for this game are misleading - for a "overwhelmingly positive" you're expecting an amazing game instead it's at most just OK. I don’t know, maybe it’s just nostalgia thing for some people, but I don’t get it. I’m not recommending it, maybe if you’re getting it for less than euro than it’s worth trying, but other way it’s not worth it. 28835991.review:
I never expected to be as captivated as i became with this game. You will die quite alot in the game, often losing many hours of progress. But each time you do, you will have learned something and after a little break, you'll probably be straight back in ready for revenge with a new build and strategy. Every close, hard fought battle is a new story that you will fondly remember or revere and fear. The only thing i was confused by was the dialogue. Theres an odd thematic flux going on, the tone shifting between dead serious, immersive, imaginative, philosophical, poetic stuff and "teh randoms kek". It's just a bit jarring for one scene to be like: "The viscous black river of blood lapped warmly at your thighs in the infinite pitch blackness. The pounding of a thousand voices from unseen creatures torments your mind as you lose grasp of time. As your sanity begins to wane, the only thing you can sense is the growing number of bodies at your feet as you sink your dagger into the demons from all sides." and then you get an encounter like: 
"A potato crawls up your leg and into your bottom." Weird attempts at humour and a few ambiguous choices aside, fantasticly fun game. It will be infuriating, but you wont forget your victory for some time when you finally make it.

28379879.review:
This game was probably the best 0.79 cents I'll spend for a long time.

I'd recommend it to anybody craving a good turn-based RPG. Progression is often heavily gated by the quality of the loot that you're able to find and craft, but that was a plus for me, because I love RNGesus with all my heart. 

Though you shouldn't need to do too much of it, grinding is actually pretty pleasant, because you won't have to wait for animations to play. Things will move as quickly as your fingers will allow them to. However, going on auto-pilot all the time is almost guaranteed to kill you: SanctuaryRPG challenges players by forcing them to adapt their strategies (which are generally pretty simple) to an extensive list of modifiers that determine how each enemy should be approached (e.g. some reflect damage, some are immune to your ultimate, some drain your mana, etc...). This is especially true for fights against bosses, which can have multiple modifiers at once.

Combat is really smooth. As always, your goal is losing the race to the end of your health bar, but there are other factors besides HP and MP to consider during fights. Every turn, you'll have to keep track of your distance from the enemy, debuff stacks, ult status, combo count, buff durations, buff costs (they tick over many turns), guarding, action commands (e.g. grapples, hit confirms, charges), and other things. The game's interface is deceptively simple, because even though each element is easy to understand on its own, juggling all of them at once in short turns is a fun challenge.

Gearing up and allocating stat points is really intuitive, but you can still make some pretty creative builds. My best character so far was a level 58 Goern Assassin with bows that focused on DEX and VIT.

I really enjoyed the music. If you're interested, I'm pretty sure you can find the full in-game OST and the piano version of 12 of the in-game tracks on youtube. 

I thought the ASCII was cool, but that's obviously just a personal thing. Some of the landscapes are pretty lackluster, but the enemies, weapons, and other larger-scale objects look gorgeous.

I'm going to keep playing, because it does a great job scratching my itch for a simple yet highly engaging RPG. I'd happily pay up to 15 bucks for it if I had to buy it again. If you're even mildly curious about what the game is like, just pony up when it goes on sale again, because reviews and gameplay footage will not do the experience justice.

28231774.review:
I'm gonna recommend this game, but I'm going to say its only worth the price of 80 cents, which is what I got it for. Get it on a sale for that, and I think you'll be happy. 

I have a lot of mixed feelings on this one, it was really hard to thumbs up it but harder to NOT thumbs up it, and I just wanna write it down dang it leave me alone, this game really doesn't deserve 50 paragraphs written about it but screw it I guess I'm doing it anyway. 

I'm gonna start with the pros first so we can get it out of the way. Biggest best pro we got here is THE MUSIC. It's really nice. I really dig it. I don't think everyone will love it, but one thing I really respect about it is that there's like 15+ songs for fighting regular enemies. Most rpgs, turn taking ones especially, will make you go into a battle and play the same song over and over and over and over for every normal battle until you hate yourself. This one just puts a buncha songs in for every enemy. SURE sometimes it'll be a stupid weak skeleton and the music will sound like a final boss, but I appreciate it anyway. 

SECOND! I like the graphics/ascii style. It's a cute style, has its charm. People who see screenshots can easily decide if they like it or not, you'll pretty much get what you expect. My only issue with it is that the background often times does not mimic the area that's being described. Like you'll supposedly be in hell and you'll see a background of mountains. There's not exactly a large supply of graphics and ascii stuff. 

Third, the battle system is all right. It's a turn taking rpg, I mean how much can you do with it, unless its a strategy turn taking rpg? It does what it does all right, it tried to even spice it up to make it feel more actioney when it isn't at all. It almost feels fast paced at times. There's some cons with it which I'll bring up later, but I'll just say it's not the worst thing. 

ANYWAY, lets get to the cons. This game has two major cons that just really hold it back. I wanted more from this game, and it's a bit frustrating. It can make it seem like a thumbs down to me and some people because it's the worst kind of thing, where you like what you're playing but you just want MORE of it. 

First and biggest con. This game is a rogue-like for some reason. It's advertised as one, for sure, it didn't come as a shock. I expected it to be different, I suppose, done better. For everything I played with this game, I just don't think it was necessary for it to be a rogue-like at all. I think making it a rogue-like held it back on many many many levels. 

So you got yourself a rogue-like and you see there's different classes! Cool, I thought they'd actually play differently, and that's where the rogue-like part comes in. Nah, they all play pretty much completely the same, but with different stats. I wouldn't mind this at all if, you know, you didn't lose everything when you die. 

Then there's the story. Maybe the story changes every time you play? Nope, it's the same exact thing, some exact quests, same exact grind. I'd be okay with the grind, I really would, but what fun is there grinding for literally 6+ hours, and then dying to a random enemy because you let it get 2 swings on you and you scrolled by the text too fast? That's what ended my last game, and I did not feel the desire to keep going. 

Going on with the grindy aspect, there's A LOT of items in the game, and a lot of randomly generated crafting items. You'll have to spend QUITE sometime making stuff if you want to get the best equipment, leveling your skills, and just in general crafting and sorting through the junk. Then, once again, if you die, its all gone. What's the reason for it?

There's just no change. You'll get some different enemies in between, but they're just healthbars, there's no "story" change in anyway whatsoever. There IS an option to play without perma-death, but it's marked as "not-recommended" and you'll lose out on "extra bonuses" whatever those are. I think it's safe to assume most people are gonna do the normal perma-death version because you don't know what's in store for you or how different it will be. 

ALL in all, I think it was just a really bad decision to make this a rogue-like. There's just too much grinding and virtually no reason to ever start a new game. It's not like Binding of Isaac where one run will take at most an hour, and you might get random items that completely change how you play the game every time. 

Imagine it's like Pokemon, but once you get a white out in Pokemon, you gotta start ALL over. Sure, it's not hard to do that at all, but why would you want to? Some people make specific challenges for that, and that's fair, but the regular game does not punish you with that because it knows that would be foolish and unfun. 

Okay, well I got that outta the way. The second big con is partially because of the first con still. 

The story. It's very shallow AT TIMES and the first two acts have the tone just ALL over the place. For a text based game, a story is very important, but I feel the writer/game dev/whoever was held back by the fact that it's a rogue-like. The descriptions and story events are written very quickly and there's not a huge burst of information, which can be done really well at times. 

But for this game, it feels it leaves more questions than answers, and a lot of the questions aren't very fun questions. There is a lack of a world in this game, it's not explained incredibly well, and doesn't go into great description of what it is even as you go on. The tone can go from being incredibly serious to dopey memes in the same sentence. There was one part where this guy is trying to rebuilt a robot in the likeness of his dead daughter right? Seems a pretty dark and sad thing, and then one of his failed creations is like "404 daughter love not found, hug.exe not responding" and it just really really takes you out of it. 

A lot of the humor can feel like "le random" at times too. There are potatoes in the world, and for whatever reason, everyone hates potatoes. A lot. It's never explained. If it was explained, maybe I could give it a pass, but it's usually just "UGH POTATOES, I HATE THEM" like and it just makes you think of "le penguin of doom XD" and you die a little on the inside. 

At the same time, the story can be pretty nice. I really liked the descriptions of hell and the hell beings. At that point they mostly did away with dumb meme jokes, and I appreciated it. Wish though that they delved deeper into that, tried to make sense of what it was doing, instead of being really sarcastic and uncaring about your story. I get the feeling like the author was afraid to try on this a lot. I see the potential, but they were worried it would look cliche and dumb. Personally, I feel it's better to try than just not try at all, but I suppose that was their way of trying, so I don't know. 

SO I wrote like 60 grillion words on a dumb 80 cent game. There were some bad times, it's very flawed, but overall I really liked the experience and I'm genuinely glad I played it, if not for the fact that it made me want to play more text/ascii adventures. Anyone who read all this disjointed garbage of a review, sorry, because it certainly sounds like I'm making it seem like its a terrible game while recommending it. 

TL;DR: 80 cents is fine, anything more than a buck, I don't think so.

25640923.review:
Wouldn't have thought I'd get into text based games, but here I am recommending one.

SanctuaryRPG is a fast paced rogue-like rpg, where you explore the world through various encounters, events and treasures. The mechanics are easy to get into after the initial reading, and the reactions can take minimal time, so the game could be progressed rather fast. Repeating previous zones doesn't feel like a grind but rather another step in the adventure as there are tons of hidden events to to find. 

Besides the main progression you have your extra managing of various buildings where you can get quests, gear and mercenaries, as well as earn money and progress in the arena. 

The music is really memorable and amazingly fitting. 

I only regret the game not having gear storage, each new piece is either replacing your current one or salvaged for parts.

Overall, highly recommended.

24895056.review:
this game is amazingly complex and brutal. normal mode alone was too much for me at first. getting a few hours into the game and coming up against an enemy who would crush me and end my campaign got extremely frustrating. but i kicked it down to easy and played it like a tutorial for a bit, learning a couple classes and the story and the massive amount of side content such as radiant side quests, or your house you can build/upgrade and dig for scrap/items. you can run your own tavern and build your relationship with different factions within the world. the ASCII graphics are also impressively detailed and the amount of depth they put into their combat system is impressive. this is easily the best text based game i've played. i have 17 hours in it and i don't have any idea where i'm at in the story with any of my characters, but i don't care. i'm having a blast levelling up and questing and exploring the 4-5 areas i've unlocked with them so far and finding a large variety of enemies/bosses/events/items. i'm hoping there's no level cap or the level cap is pretty high, because i love how many different things you can put points in when you level up. the class based skills, the general skills and weapon skills. you can become a specialized badass in just about anything. wanna be a mage who wields greatswords and/or bows instead of the classic staves/wands/daggers? you can. with the overwhelming amount of things there is to do and discover in this game, i don't have enough space in this review to list it all and i'm constantly finding more all the time.

the bottom line is, if you like text based games or wanna try a text based RPG, this is the best one i've found so far and i wholeheartedly recommend you try it out. wait for it to go on sale if you're worried about the $8 price tag, but i assure you there is easily a hundred hours worth of content to this game.

The game was pretty fun!  Good graphics, funny, hard, and I enjoyed the hell out of a 5 hour session.  Next day, I load up the game and it synced the savefile of my badass character with a corrupt one.  Character had 1 hp, all my gold and items are gone, everything was lost.

I would highly suggest not putting your gaming time into a game which may or may not have all your hard work saved for the next time you play it.  When I read the other bad reviews, many complained of bad programming and now I'd have to agree.  A sync should overwrite an older file with a newer file, but in this case it replaced my local mainsave_black.dat with the older one on the steam cloud and completely screwed me over.

Don't waste your time.

24051193.review:
SanctuaryRPG is a peculiar mix of brilliant and lazy design decisions. In concept, it's a turn-based, menu-driven distillation of all the "number go up" bits that make games in the mold of Diablo so addictive. In some places, the game delivers on that concept in a way just short of genius; in others, it goes "eh, whatever, this will do" and calls it a day.

[b]Brilliant[/b]: The battle system is complex and engaging despite its extreme abstraction. Attack and defense abilities, status effects, monster affixes, range (sort of), weapon properties, character class features, and more besides--the better you learn these things, the more successful you'll be. Various elements require that you stay mindful of what's going on rather than run on autopilot, lest you miss opportunities or suffer dangerous consequences.

[b]Lazy[/b]: The UI is atrocious. You have to mash Enter after every menu choice, as if you were working with a terminal prompt instead of pushing virtual buttons. The mouse does nothing, but the game doesn't bother to hide the cursor in fullscreen mode.

[b]Brilliant[/b]: There are tons of ways to get experience, gold, and items. If you're feeling behind the curve against the current crop of storyline foes, you don't necessarily have to farm lower-level monsters--you can take on some level-matched foes in the arena, read books in the Library, tend patrons in your tavern, or craft, all of which will move you along at least a bit.

[b]Lazy[/b]: Some of these activities, though, are deadly boring, and you'll roll your eyes when some new system presents itself and it turns out to be yet another thing that awards experience, gold, and random items. Crafting? Experience and random items (you get only minimal input into what you craft). Tavern? Gold, experience, and "gifts" from patrons that are, yes, random items. Fetch quests? Experience and random items. There's all of one well-hidden quest that gives you anything unique or interesting.

[b]Brilliant[/b]: The aesthetic. Well, maybe not [i]brilliant[/i] exactly, but at least gutsy and unusual. The ASCII art is well done and the music catchy.

[b]Lazy[/b]: The art you see has nothing to do with what you're doing, most of the time. You can be trudging through a hellish underworld, and still see pictures of green forests and blue oceans. The writing is terrible; there's a nonsensical main plot about robots and fallen angels that tries to get you to take it seriously even as the rest of the game cracks jokes about potatoes. (If you can even call them jokes. The author seems to think that simply saying the word "potato" is the height of hilarity.) Don't bother talking to NPCs--their dialogue is bland and doesn't change from start to finish.

[b]Brilliant[/b]: Itemization is very well designed. You can't stash old equipment, and each item has at most a core attack/defense stat, two attribute boosts, and an affix. That means that you're almost always trading something off when you upgrade, prompting reconsideration of what's in your other slots. Just changing out a weapon of one category for another can drastically change your play style.

[b]Lazy[/b]: Permadeath. I don't take offense to the idea in principle--Nethack, that age-old Roguelike, is one of my favorite games of all time. But it doesn't fit at all here. There's not enough variety from one game to the next, games take too long to proceed to the latter stages, and there isn't enough of a skill learning curve to justify it. I recommend playing a couple short games to get the idea, then once you settle on a build you like, backing up your save files as you go.

In the end, I do give this game the thumbs-up because it's such an unusual specimen, and I found it enjoyable enough to play to conclusion on the standard difficulty. But know what you're getting into: it is, in many ways, half-assed.

23779721.review:
Very demanding of your time, patience, and inner worrywart. Any simple mistake with laughably cost you. You can start out from whatever classes you want, and the game douses you in a list of perks to the point where you feel nearly invincible,  not to mention the mouth-watering bonuses your weapons, armors, and miscs offer. At the same time, however, you ABSOLUTELY cannot overestimate yourself when you pick up this game, or it will cost you getting carried away. Even blindly grinding mid-level mobs can sometimes sucker punch you and knock you dead.

Every ounce of music in the game is enjoyable, from the basicness of the low-level skeleton fights to the errogenous coin ticks of the tavern. I'd buy a soundtrack if I could.

Though the graphics cleverly implicate many integers for use of shading and texture, it gets kind of hard to tell what things are until you take a second to look at them, so that gets kind of cumbersome.

It's also a very flexible game: you can either sit down, grab some chips and soda, and score through the game as far as you want, or play bit by bit every so often. As demanding as it is, you can choose your own pace and enjoy it however quickly you'd like.

No matter what class you have, it's important to spend some time learning every move you have in your arsenal (you have two sets of consecutive attacks that alternate for every finisher you do), which adds on to the whole patience business.

If you like being rewarded with secrets, then find another game. You more or less risk your booty when you find secrets in the overworld, which gets highly irritating, especially when you find yourself up against a high-level mob from one. However, some other times the game can offer some neat jazz like overpowered weaponry, though it's all in a coin flip in the end.

One of the larger bits of the game I don't like is the raunchy difficulty of the game. I actually could not stand to finish it even to date, simply because of how unrewarding and punishing the game feels. Though if you're the kind of sick twisted bastard who gets a kick out of that, then it's your grave you're digging.

Otherwise, it's a nice game if you're looking for pure-hearted challenge and shoving druid bear claws up skellys' arses. Just don't expect any justice in the rewards you get!

I haven't gotten too far into this game but I'm enjoying it very much. The ASCII presentation reminds me of old dial-up BBS door games, but the story and combat go beyond arcadey games like those. Combat is a strategic balance of managing your resources (damage, health, mana, debuffs) while whittling away at your foe. Combat is combo-based and you're rewarded for long chains of attacks which tempt you into fighting without healing. Permadeath makes the game more exciting since it encourages you to take risks.

Quite a deep game despite the deceptively simplistic presentation. Very compelling and detailed, plus it's got a sense of humour. Great game!

This feels like something right out of my childhood.  A quirky, ascii, encounter driven RPG with an actual decent story, good characters, a great sense of humor, and just a charm and finesse that really hit home.

If you like quirky/original takes on nostalgic genres and art styles, by all meand give this one a try. 22926147.review:
[h1]就像一颗种子，它开出了无数的花[/h1]
---------------------
[h1]>99%的人不会喜欢这个游戏，而我是那1%[/h1]
想要说明这一点很简单，在游戏画质越来越好、乃至有了VR体验的今天，很难会有人关注、喜欢上这么一款全ASCII字符界面的游戏....
哦，先别急着慌...更糟糕的我还没说完呢：这个游戏，不支持鼠标操纵，每一步操作，都需要你在键盘上键入相关按键，很繁琐。
......
Anyway，我知道，看到这的你已经打算要走了。
不过别急，也许你对这个游戏一点也不来电，但或许，你会对我接下来讲的故事感兴趣。

[h1]>起源[/h1]
你也许听说过Roguelike这个词，但你很可能不知道所谓的Rogue-like(类Rogue)里的like指的是like什么。
上世纪80年代，有两位“不务正业”的软件工程师Michael Toy与 Glenn Wichman，试图制作一个有着无限重复体验可能性的游戏。
于是他们花了两个礼拜（据说），做出了一个对后世影响颇深的游戏。是的，就是《Rogue》。这款游戏运行于UNIX系统，是当时最早的图形界面游戏。

在《Rogue》之后，其实，还有一款名为《NetHack》的游戏。这款游戏的伟大之处，在于它定义了“战斗、探索然后强化自己”的概念。这个概念被广泛的借鉴，如以撒中的各种奖励房和道具。

而作为这个类型的创始者，《Rogue》主要为之后无数的Roguelike提供了以下几种主要的特点：
1. 随机生成的迷宫/地图
2. 复杂的但有趣的游戏系统
3. ASCII字符界面

发展到现在，“ASCII字符界面”已经不再通行。但随机生成的乐趣依然备受玩家追捧。
如大家耳熟能详的以撒的结合。从以撒开始，又有着一大批相似或有趣的模仿作（攻城英雄啦，核子王座，滚弹地牢等等等）。
这些游戏也已经不再使用ASCII字符界面，更多的是采取像素或者复古的画面风格。

那么，“ASCII字符界面”都到哪里去了？
一个很著名的仿Rogue游戏《矮人要塞/Dwarf Fortress》则参照了《Rogue》的设定，如全随机的开局、地图、剧情历史及字符界面。而从《矮人要塞》出发，则又衍生出了许多仿矮人要塞的游戏，比较出名的如矮人村庄、发条帝国。当然，还包括魔性的异星工厂，他的开发者自身就是矮人要塞的狂热粉。顺便再说一句，MC的作者Notch也坦言他从这个游戏中获取了灵感。（有兴趣的玩家可以来试试画质增强版的矮人要塞，地址：链接：
http://pan.baidu.com/s/1o8d6QyI 密码：883f）

[b]既然提到了“ASCII字符界面”，我们终于可以回到正题上来了。[/b]

《字符神殿：黑盒版》全由ASCII字符来体现画面。你肯定很难想象，游戏是如何用你键盘上的那些玩意来表现数量惊人的武器和怪物的。具体来说，是近1400多种武器和装备、300余种字符画风的怪物。同时，游戏融入了经典的Ruguelike元素，战斗，探险，进入遗迹，从偶遇的石碑上发现世界的真正秘密。

还记得我们的标题么？《Rogue》就像一颗种子，它开出了无数的花。作为其中的一朵，《字符神殿/SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition》就是这样一款有着很深Rogue烙印的游戏。你只有一次机会，你会随机触发任务、发现地牢，然后展开一段独特的冒险；你会因为不小心杀死巨龙而成为王国的勇士，也会因为遇见古老的献祭仪式而被迫变为巫妖......

[h1]>听起来不错...这个游戏还有其他有趣的么？[/h1]

*说出来你可能不信，我在8级的草原遇到了前来觅食的巨龙。LOL
*说出来我自己都不信，我居然干死了巨龙......靠一个莫名的心脏要害暴击。（随机大法好！）
*摘下眼镜，画面变得栩栩如生。
*战斗不只是简单的一个"Attack"，而是更具体的肢体行动，如肘击、绕后....每个动作都有不同的攻击效果（致残、晕眩等状态，多达30种）。
*不错的8位音乐（游戏自带免费OST[含钢琴版OST]）
*超多的职业搭配...以及搞笑的发式
*众多可解锁的要素

如果你玩到比较后期一点的话：

*在商店看上了一把极品武器但是没有钱付款怎么办？
我会告诉你，我选择在天黑之后，用一把在洞穴探险发现的神铲挖开后墙，直接偷走商品。
*美貌的女子究竟是不是Futa？我决定掀开她的裙甲一探究竟。
*地牢！遗迹！木乃伊....哦，还有不死的巫妖....

[h1]>现在，你对这个游戏有点兴趣了么？[/h1]
-----------------------------------------
杉果打折(2016.5.11)只要3.75￥哦~只要一瓶王老吉的价钱哟~即能喜加一，又能装装逼，这样的游戏，不要450，只要3.75，还不快行动起来，在加一的路上朝着粉枪前进？！
传送门：
http://www.sonkwo.com/products/1600

这篇评测写得很泛，但我真的是不知道怎么去介绍一个画面复古、操作繁琐而且永远不可能有汉化的游戏。
不可能每个人都爱上这一类的游戏，甚至大部分人一看到这个画风就直接关页面了。
如果你看到这了，说明我的努力至少取得了一点成效。=w=

*注：文中提到的99%、1%等数字均为抽象的比较概念，而非具象的科学数字。
*注：以上包括Roguelike之类的内容，不能完全作为正确的史观，仅供参考及大方面的了解。如果有兴趣了解更多，可以到[url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roguelike]->这里<-[/url]查看。
*Tips:F12截图,截图在游戏Screenshots文件夹里。

22304307.review:
What a remarkable game. When i got the game i was not expecting much except some nostalgic ascii goodness i grew up with during the dial-up BBS hey days of the 90's. Turns out the game consists of a deep  game engine/combat-engine coated with really retro text-ui. Basically it seems to me that the devs - who have obviously played the classics just decided to make a game that pays homage to old classics and also make to it 'the best there is' using modern technology but still make it look like it's a old game. And by that i mean menus and everything are retro but all works smoothly - unless it's supposed to move sluggishly. Also the rich sound world in the background betrays the fact this game is no retro technically. 

So should you buy it? Depends. Rogue-like players will like it but as some players have pointed out the joke-like nature of encounters and certain linearity will wear you down in the longer run. Game will require some stamina from the player. things are revealed in time and the pacing is slow. 

However if are you just curious what the game is like then get it right away. It's price is not bad and easily worth it. It simply a unique game in my library - there is no other game i can directly compare this to and i do have a pretty decent set of roguelikes. 

Many weird wtf moments with this game. For me just the surprise elements i have encountered during the first 10 hours and the constant finding of new things has kept the game very fresh. And i have only tried two classes as of yet. At 10 hours i am still curious over what i will find next. 

Game claims to be the "world's first fully-ASCII game to grace the Steam platform," and things look right now this game will put the bar very high for late comers.

22302993.review:
I will admit, this game feels like a joke that I didn't get. But that being said, it is hard to write a good review about a joke you didn't find funny.

Pros:

* Deep and engaging, has enough content for hundreds of hours
* High replayability
* Very addictive

Cons:
* Combat is skillful, but sometimes just revolves around luck, some encounters are just not in your favor at all
* There are some bugs with weapons, particularly one that turns Resistance weapons into Brotherhood weapons, making the faction system useless
* Video options are VERY limited
* Some actions make the screen flicker and it can hurt your eyes (talking to you, tavern patrons)

Overall, I highly recommend the game. It's unfortunate that the game is mostly abandoned by both people and the developers. Bugs are still present, and there's not a lot of useful information on wikis. If you need something to kill hours and hours of time, and you don't mind ascii graphics or roguelike elements, this game is perfect for you.

It isn't about exploring... it's about mashing buttons and getting feedback. 

Playing this game at night on a mechanical keyboard sounds like doing your taxes aggressively.

While I question the true, long term value of the game, I cannot deny that it is highly addictive.

Beneath the simple surface lies... depth through decisions. And tons of item rolls. And reading books. And selling beer. And digging holes.

It manages to blend turn based combat, reading, and action RPG sensibilites into one pot and stirs them vigorously via the "1 enter 2 enter 3 enter 3 enter" method.

Crafting is way more complicated than it appears, or maybe not. 

I sit down at night, intending to play for an hour....

...many hours later, I hallucinate a woman telling me to get up and do something else.

That is my story.

I'm a role-player since I'm a little man, it's been like 13 years now I'm playing board RPGs, and I told myself "Should I buy this game ? Will I find what I'm searching for ? What am I searching for exactly anyway.. ?". 

75% off -> less than 2€, okay Steam, you got me !

I - DO - NOT - REGRET - ANYTHING (Don't get me wrong, I regret things, so many things. Like "no need to heal, let's just hit that f*cking bird with a... Am I.. DEAD ?! A bird freaking two shots me ?!". Those bad decisions I regret, but from them I've learnt how to survive)
You don't have proper towns to visit, proper NPCs to interact with, but the game doesn't really need it.. it's a fighting simulation, the menu let you go across shops anytime you want/need between fights, you can talk with NPC but no major things are at stake, the humour whatsoever is really much appreciated in my opinion.

My advice : buy the game, get comfortably numb and BE PATIENT.. The learning scheme is kinda like that : Play -> Die + learn -> Play again -> learn -> Die anyway -> Ragequit -> Play with more knowledge and more determination (like, 1h later, I'm not that much of a tryhard-guy though and I played it again and again, because that game wants to be appreciated, it has so many things you'd love..)
