21440841.review:
SanctuaryRPG is a rogue-like adventure with an emphasis on charmingly goofy writing and a surprisingly detailed combat system hidden beneath a primitive-looking interface. It also has a catchy and enjoyable soundtrack.

The central gameplay loop [i]does[/i] seem monotonous, albeit instantly familiar:

1. Kill things.
2. Level up; find randomised loot.
3. Repeat, watching your numbers increase, until you can take on the boss of the current Act.
4. Kill the boss.
5. Proceed to the next Act and repeat.

(This is occasionally interrupted by inconveniently dying, cursing at the screen, and rolling a new character—or, on Softcore difficulty, respawning with 0 gold and 0 EXP. Also, there are a few side activities that produce EXP and loot with varying amounts of player effort, but they are of course only temporary distractions from the main loop.)

But hey, if the game were only as boring as I just made it sound, I wouldn't be recommending it. So, here's why I'm addicted to this silly and engrossing game:

1. The combat system instantly grabbed me. Chaining attacks creates combos, which raise the multiplier for your ult. You can (and should) reposition yourself to put distance between you and the enemy, to break their guard, to dodge an attack with a lead-up, or to thwart their missile lock-on. Oh, wait—they ensnared you? Cut yourself free. They wounded you? You'll have to heal or you won't be able to reposition as effectively. They poisoned you? Too many poison stacks and you'll go blind. And there's so much more to it than I can describe here. It's thrilling; looking at the combat screen and entering commands, I can't help but feel like a wizard.

2. The music is surprisingly good and goes beyond what one would expect from a game with these visuals. The battle themes in particular are stuck in my head.

3. The writing and enemy design ranges from silly meta humour to lightly engaging adventure-drama. I want to see what stupid random event will pop up, just as much as I want to see what happens next in the (semi-)serious story.

To give a more personal testimonial: I got someone hooked on this game, despite his dislike for typing and reading walls of text. The combat gameplay and the music won him over. That's a real triumph in my book.

Go ahead and give the demo a whirl!

TL:DR? Worth full price but a real fucking gem on sale.

     110 minutes from one sitting. Some mixed emotion about this game so far but moreso good than bad...
This game is visually simple yet stunning. To make this variety of varying images with ascii and an entire text based battle system, I mean I've done programming and that would kill my soul... to death.brains oozing out onto the little chunks of skull and broken keyboard. That being said the end result is really fucking well done. And then there's the soundtrack...

     The music which so far can vary by menu.enemy.action is a complete homage to old school 8 bit dungeon crawling, and; still seems fresh, and well done and not so far repetitive. To sum it up its like Final Fantasy and father's of Death metal DEATH, sat down with dragon's quest and RoadRash 3d on the playstation with the driving and specific purpose of creating the right and fit soundtrack for this game with this game in mind and this game as an altar to 8-bit throwback gods who demand more out of their Audio RPG elements to be appeased.

     The gameplay is what really sets this game apart, it's daftly simple but if you aren't paying attention you'll miss a lot of sublte elements that will make the game play in your favor so it takes a while to master (again 110 minutes in...theres still stuff being introduced into the battle system as I progress.

     So this game really hit me as a standout game, I mean I just got done with Tom Clancy's The Division Beta and this game has more standout unique elements to it that the beta...(I may just be getting hit in the face with the nostalgia stick)and when you talk about AAA titles with less to set it about from its peers than an 8 dollar indie release (that I got for 2$ and yes it was like a sigh of releif to have finally put some money on an actual gem.

A friend asked me, "I like roguelikes, how is this one?" to which I said, "SanctuaryRPG is not a roguelike. It's a text adventure game." 21400438.review:
They had me at potatoes. Then it got better.
This is my story.

I am honestly totally obsessed with this game right now. I have a really hard time putting it down, even for necessary things like feeding the cat and going to bed.
There is a HUGE learning curve right at first, so expect to die a lot. There's a reason the softcore difficulty level is Not Recommended. Like all Roguelike games, you learn from every failure. It really makes you question what's actually a failure, and what's just a learning experience for next time.
I love the art style in this game so much. It's amazing what you can do with a little imagination, creative sound effects, and the ASCII system. It's simple, but it drives your imagination into overdrive. With a few keystrokes, some extremely fitting music, sound effects, and imagination, I go from sitting in front of a very detailed text-based battle to a heart-pounding fight for my life.

Fair warning, while I thoroughly recommend this game to all rpg lovers and especially people who have a taste for classic-style games, this game is one hell of a drug. I dream it, I see it in real life now, and, most importantly, I will never look at potatoes the same way ever, ever, EVER again.

20889691.review:
This was an unexpected purchase courtesy of Humble Bundle's monthy bundle and while I played some old BBS games like Legend of the Red Dragon in the past, I didn't think I would enjoy a text-based RPG.  I was wrong.

SanctuaryRPG is a multifaceted game where you juggle multiple tasks.  On top of questing and killing baddies for experience, you're doing quests for the local blacksmith in exchange for rewards.  Plus you can mine for resources if you want to craft your own gear.  There's a local tavern in the area and a coliseum to test your strength (and do some endgame grinding I assume.)  Also libraries, taverns, random drops, and other goodies.  It's full of stuff to consume your time.

Also, the developer has a strange and unhealthy fascination with potatoes.  You'll see.

In spite of any initial objection you may have to ASCII graphics, I can say it's quite fun to play.  The music will get stuck in your head too.  I'm 20 hours in and I still haven't finished it.

20685361.review:
[h1]All Is Potato.[/h1]

[b]SanctuaryRPG = Potato + Ye Olden BBS Door RPG + Robot Jerks + More Potato[/b]

This is a game unlike most others.  It eschews accessibility in favor of being at times deliberately obtuse.  It is truly "oldschool" in a very real sense rather than simply appealing to the "8-Bit" aesthetic.  I think those of us that like the game most were probably those that played text-based adventures in glorious monochrome.  Or played countless sessions of Legend of the Red Dragon on ancient and likely now extinct BBSes.  Or engaged in awkward roleplay at 3am on some forsaken MUD out there.

If you understand any of that at all, then this is the game for you.  You are also probably like me, getting old, and seeing a game like this helps you convince yourself the things you enjoyed in yesteryear are NOT in fact entirely irrelevant!

If, on the otherhand, you didn't understand any of that but still have an appreciation for ASCII art, catchy beep-boopy music, and grind heavy RPG mechanics, then you too may find this game worthwhile.  Whippersnapper.

All of the gameplay consists of entering (mostly one character) commands as highlighted on the current screen.  At first, most of this will be simply an encounter crawl, a series of battles using a handful of attacks and abilities.  Combat is turn based and text heavy.  You need to pay close attention to both your own and your enemy's condition, and carefully chain together your attacks and simultaneously avoid the power attacks of your enemy.  There is a very definite rhythm to it all, and you can die very easily if you don't master it.

As you progress, you will unlock an increasing amount of side-activites and quests.  These involve running a tavern, expanding your player home, mining iron, crafting gear, arena battles and random dungeons, among many other things.  However, despite the number of activities the end result is mostly about gaining gold, XP, or a RNG item reward.  Speaking of RNG, I hope you like it or at least tolerate it, because this game uses it [i]heavily[/i].  As a result, it pays to invest points in a few different weapon proficiencies as it can be difficult to come across a good weapon of the one specific type that you want.

Apart from the ASCII graphics, which are fairly attractive but also not the best I've seen, there is also a very complementary soundtrack that is very retro-inspired without being too chip-tuney.  If you have a sweet tooth for nostalgia, prepare your mouth for cavities.

Last, but not least, is the humor of the game.  There are plots and sub-plots to unravel, but most of that is lost in the extremely silly and "le random" type of humor in the narrative.  I actually found it pretty amusing for the most part, but boy oh boy am I tired of seeing the word "potato".

[i]Grab your Potato and roll a character if you...[/i]

[list]

[*] Used to play BBS doors.  Seriously, just buy it already.  The only thing lacking here would be the competitive multi-player, but this otherwise could be mistaken for a BBS classic.

[*] Love grindey, RNG-ey, numbery RPG-ey gameplay.

[*] Can't get enough of retro ASCII type stuff.

[*] Have an unhealthy fixation on potatoes that causes you to rub them all over your body in exchange for gifts from strangers.

[/list]

[i]Press (N) to (N)ope out of this one if you...[/i]

[list]

[*] Have no interest in retro ASCII whatsoever.  There's, uh, not gonna be much for you to look at.

[*] Loathe nonsensical humor. POTATO LOL SO RANDOM!!!1!11

[*] Have requirements for gameplay that involve anything other than navigating menu screens.

[*] Hate grinding, because that's kinda the focus here.

[*] Feel that the only fit use for potatoes is food, not weaponry, companionship, objects of worship, or pleasure.

[/list]

[u]The Bottom Line[/u]

Although this game gets "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews, and despite the fact that I recommend it myself, it is actually [i]not[/i] for everyone.  I personally love it as a throwback to mostly forgotten games of the past, for the ASCII art, for the fun assortment of grinding activities, and even for the heavily potato-based humor.  However, I can easily see all of those things being negatives for another person.  One man's potato is another man's radish, or so the old saying probably goes.

For my part, the only thing I really felt missing is a solid multiplayer aspect.  Most of the great BBS door games of old were heavily competitive beyond simple leaderboard rankings.  It often entailed a lot of direct PvP, raids, and even things like ship combat and kingdom warfare.

I'd love to see a sequel to Sanctuary that kept the single-player grinding and expanded upon it with competitive multiplayer activites.  That would make the game a true Yukon Gold, rather than the more common Idaho Russet.

20532901.review:
American Standard Code For Information Interchange : tel est le nom barbare et peu engageant de cette norme de codage de caractères informatiques que les “nerds”, informaticiens ou dinosaures, connaissent sous le nom d’ASCII que l’on utilise encore de nos jours sous forme de pop-art : on en fait des dessins, des animations, des logos et tout un tas d’objets dérivés qui se sont peu à peu greffés à la culture “geek”. “Ca nous fait une belle jambe!” me direz-vous… Et bien sachez que fut un temps on faisait des jeux avec ses caractères.

C’est quoi l’ASCII ?

Lorsque l’on vous parle de retro gaming, vous vient immédiatement à l’esprit le petit plombier moustachu sautant sur ses plateformes 8 bits, si il est un vénérable ancêtre médiévale du jeu video moderne, les jeux en ASCII représentent quant à eux le paléolithique du monde video ludique. Durant ma jeunesse j’imprimais des cartes en vue de dessus faites avec ce fabuleux ASCII afin de jouer avec mes potes à divers jeux de rôles.

C’est également avec notre ami ASCII qu’apparurent les premiers Rogue Like et autres Dongeon Crawler sur ordinateur, et c’est ainsi que là où l’humain lambda ne voyait que des formes vaguement géométriques sur une feuille ou un écran qu’un joueur avisé voyait des couloirs sombres de labyrinthes complexes, des escaliers piégés, des monstres ou des PNJ. Ainsi sont nés certains jeux mythiques comme Moria ou Rogue qui furent bien connus des possesseurs de Macintosh, Amiga Commodore et autres Atari ST sans pour autant avoir eu un succès phénoménal, la faute en revient à leurs graphismes minimalistes et au moteur principal de ces jeux : l’imagination.

SanctuaryRPG : Black Edition est un jeu de rôles créé par Black Shell Games utilisant l’ASCII à la fois comme illustration mais reprenant également certaines mécaniques de jeu propres à de très anciens titres. C’est donc dans une ambiance de nostalgie pour certains et de découverte pour d’autres que ce jeu vous propose en vue à la première personne d’entrer dans un monde extrèmement riche afin d’y incarner un personnage que vous aurez créé de toutes pièces et qui aura pour quête de libérer le monde du joug maléfique d’une terrible matronne. Votre arme principale sera votre clavier : il est chaudement recommandé qu’il soit muni d’un pavé numérique, ici pas de souris ni de manette on fait tout à l’ancienne.

Lire le test complet sur Game Side Story: http://www.gamesidestory.com/2015/03/14/gametest-sanctuary-rpg-black-edition-pc/

20032916.review:
Если из других обзоров вы мало что поняли, то попытаюсь прояснить, в чем суть игры. Надеюсь, поможет.

Во-первых, это таки не RPG, а, скорее, текстовый квест навроде древнего ДИКТАТОРА еще на спектрумах. Да, чисто технически элементы RPG здесь присутствуют - прокачка, отыгрыш персонажей, даже какие-никакие NPC, но по сути - это навороченный текстовый квест. 

Во-вторых, суть геймплея сводится к выбору вариантов из предложенных на экране. Так проходят бои, так ведется крафт, так можно обустраивать жилье. Ну, и диалоги, конечно, тоже, хотя они тут чисто формальные.

В-третьих, графика. Это не то ASCII, которое есть в NetHack, DwarfForteress или ADOM. Графика здесь - это своеобразные ASCII иллюстрации, а не строительный материал для уровней, персонажей и т.д. На их месте могло быть видео в разрешении 4K или вообще ничего не быть - игра от этого не изменилась бы ни на йоту.

Четвертое - RPG-составляющие. Есть класы персонажей, но игра за них не сильно отличается. Паладин бьет мечом, маг - файерболом. Слова другие, суть та же. Есть навыки, их можно прокачивать. На тактику влияет минимально. Есть статсы. Есть перки. Много перков. Есть главный квест и побочные задания. Последние сводятся к сбору определенного лута. Во всяком случае в начале, но, думается мне, и дальше подвижек в этом направлении не будет. NPC есть, но толку от них ноль. Чисто поржать, да и то на один раз. Есть разные виды оружия, броня, амулеты, но на тактику боя они тоже почти не влияют.

Пятое. Бои. Самая фановая часть игры. Собственно, 90% игры - это бои. Напоминаю, что геймплей здесь - это выбор вариантов действия. Т.е. управление не прямое, как в большинстве RPG, а командами - ударить таким-то ударом, применить такой-то скилл, поменять позицию и т.д. Если внимательно читать, что пишут на экране, и не лезть к мобам слишком высоких уровней по отношению к вашему, то победить не сложно. Вариативность большая. Много врагов, много видов действий, много особых свойств. Впрочем, осваивается это богатство быстро. И так же быстро надоедает, увы.

Итого: играется легко, быстро и весело. Однако для длительного прохождения слишком скучна - нет серьезных квестов, нет нормальных NPC, случайные события случайны во всех смыслах, абсурдный юмор быстро надоедает, бои проходятся фактически одной и той же тактикой и т.д. И даже дополнительные возможности вроде интересной системы крафта или возможности содержать таверну ситуацию кардинально не исправляют. В принципе можно рекомендовать как  способ убить свободный часик в перерыве между чем-то более серьезным.

19810159.review:
Summary (for tl;dr readers):

I love this game! It's innovative yet keeping within the core practices of old-school roguelikes. Play it for at least 10-15 hours to truly appreciate it. 9/10.

Pros:
-Beautiful ASCII art
-Wonderful soundtrack
-In-depthmechanics and gradual learning curve
-An old-school roguelike that is not a clone of Angband/Nethack/ADOM
-Funny
-Good crafting system
-Solid RPG elements
-Good replayability

Cons:
-It could do with some more content and rebalancing
-The story is a bit lacking
-The encounters (events) can get a bit too random

Possible caveats (i.e. things you might either love or hate):
-Absolutely unforgiving (in non-softcore modes)
-Repetitive combat (it's a design choice, but it can get frustrating)
-The community is rather small
-Very different from Angband/Nethack/ADOM, and somewhat less in-depth
-No new-school roguelike progression (a la Rogue Legacy), but progressing in the game will unlock new options
-It has a weird obsession with potatoes

Detailed review:

Sanctuary RPG is an ASCII roguelike that does not follow the steps of Angband/ADOM/Nethack, so if that is what you are expecting you might be disappointed. The exploration is done via menu choices, rather than moving your character around a map, and so is the combat, dialogue, and pretty much everything else. The immersion is achieved, instead, through some rather stunning ASCII art, an absolutely outstanding soundtrack, and various interactions with enemies and NPCs. The game mechanics, and various menus, are complex enough to keep things interesting throughout the game, but not so much to become overwhelming; this is also achieved by new features, skills, and areas becoming gradually available as your character levels up.

If what you are missing, however, is the unforgiving nature of old roguelikes, then look no further. Sanctuary RPG looks deceptively friendly at first, with its light humour and digestible chunks of text, but the moment you get distracted or overconfident, you're dead, no mater how overpowered you felt ten seconds ago. The game is rather difficult to master, not because the underlying mechanics are complicated, but because you have to be very careful with all your decisions, just like in any old roguelike worth its salt. I have played it for over 20 hours and never managed to get past act 2. For those looking for a less frustrating experience, the game also has a softcore mode, with reduced loot drops and no permadeath.

As some reviewers have mentioned, the combat does get a bit repetitive, again, like in any old-school roguelike, and that is exactly how most of my characters meet their untimely demise: I get distracted and miss a crucial step to heal or use an ability. This is a design choice, I believe, and one I understand and accept, however much it frustrates me to lose my precious wizards to it again and again.

Some of the text could do with a spell check, but there are no major grammatical mistakes, just a couple of sentences here and there that sound a bit odd. As much as the content has grown and been improved over the last year or so, I would love to see more dialogue choices for the NPCs you meet in every adventure, as those get a bit old after a while and lack depth. I also feel that some of the randomly generated loot needs a bit of a rebalance, but that may also be a design choice to prevent characters from getting too strong too quickly.

I think my main gripe is with the small size of the community that plays this game. It is very difficult to find guides, and even the wiki is barely there. As such, it is rather difficult to compare strategies with other players. Many players seem to abandon this game after a few hours, which I think isn't anough to fully appreciate it. And while it is fun, and in-theme with the old-school roguelike vibe (I didn't have walkthroughs for Angband back in the 90s!) to discover the game by trial and error, sometimes it also gets a bit frustrating.

All in all, however, I truly love this game. It's balanced, it's fun, and it's unforgiving in a very familiar way, while also being surprisingly innovative. If any of its elements appeal to you, you can't go wrong for that price, give it a chance. And get the soundtrack too! :)

19267460.review:
Sanctuary Plays like a single player MUD. 
If you ever wanted to dip into text based online games but find them intimidating or to rapid paced, this is a much slower, more friendly RPG introduction to ASCII textual adventures. Set your nostalgia back to the 80s because Sanctuary returns us to the days of IBM floppy disk playstyle, but adds all the swish new techniques of today's slickest MUDs. 
The RPG elements are top notch and more often than not innovative over today's AAA games. The character class combinations are incredibly fun. The system is easy enough to understand, so one is never bogged down with endless cumbersome keyboard commands. The controls make sense, are to the point, displayed on the screen and turn-based, so you can learn at your own pace. The risk factor makes the game feel very realistic and often even frightening. Charming townspeople and chilling dungeons alike await intrepid adventurers. The music is wonderful and worth buying as a DLC. It evokes feelings of old Nobuo Uematsu fantasies with lots of crunchy nintendo blip goodness. The graphics may seem simple, but they are incredibly complex and beautiful. Just try to draw these yourself! Every monster and treasure is well rendered in ASCII and better than 3D graphics in this case, as it allows the player to imagine a fair amount of the world as well. 
Crafting is great. Quests are enjoyable. The fightng is damned fun. The limit break system is dynamic and carries over across battles. Stored TP can then be used for difficult battles, opening up with that devastating special attack. That's just one small example of how complex the battling is. All the while, it never gets hard to control, overwhelming, or confusing... but don't go thinking this roguelike holds yer hand, it does not. The player is soon plunged into a world of danger & excitement. I fear for my characters' lives. Their experiences feel very real.
Black Edition is wicked & well polished. Worth buying again.

10/10 - Better RPG than Skyrim.

(playtime also on Desura & inaccurate)

18965084.review:
I don't know why this game gets so many positive reviews. The only thing to recommend it is the basic design of the combat system, which is decently solid. The rest of the game plays like a satirical take on Free to Play games. That is, the whole game is variations on the theme of "make the player waste their time jumping through UI hoops to earn tiny incremental rewards." Just about everything in this games takes at least 6 button-presses more than it should, maybe so that it can provide the illusion of variation in gameplay where there is none.

Pros:
+ Decent basic combat system.

Cons:
- Designed to make you press as many buttons as possible to accomplish as little as possible.
- The whole game is just one giant grindfest. Even non-combat activities are designed to to take many pointless steps.
- Insanely linear. No exploration. You just select "Continue on in plot" from the menu.
- Permadeath starts EVERYTHING over from the beginning. This wouldn't be so bad if you didn't waste so much time building stuff up every time you play, all for only incremental benefits.
- The "humor" in this game is so random it's not funny, with some exceptions.

SRPG is an ASCII game that's part rougelike, part RPG, part DND, and part "magic is still the best"

Should you get this game? Yes. Experience it.
Don't play it with a headache though.

7/10

細かい相違点は色々有るが、根本の戦闘の楽しさは味わえるはず。

・キャラクタービルドが非常に豊富で、周回後の隠しステータスなどもある。
Lvが3桁以上行き、各職につきセーブスロットが2つずつ搭載されているのでやり込み要素は濃い目。
全体的に割合ダメ上昇アビリティなど大味と思わせつつしっかりとしたバランスになっており、レベル差経験値減退もある為、シングルプレイハクスラにありがちな「強い武器を事故で手に入れてしまうと後半が楽すぎてダレる」ということもない。
また戦闘そのもののシステムについても基本はターンベースでシンプルながら、後半になるほど特殊持ちの敵が増えて読みとタイミングが重要になってくるので終盤まで楽しめる。
反面、そういう意味では一方的な敵ボッコが出来るゲームではないので、無双感を味わいたい人には向いていないかもしれない。

・ストーリーは下ネタやメタネタも割と有るが、土台はしっかりしている。
要するに「悪い奴が暴れてるからぶっ倒して来い」というド王道モノだが、シュールかつ独特なテキストが得も言えぬ高揚感を与えてくれる。
勿論全部英語なので読めないと辛いかもしれないが、簡単な単語だけ拾っていっても雰囲気だけは味わえるのではないだろうか。

・プレビュー画の通り全てが文字とAAだけで構成されている(中身は画像だが)ため、非常に操作レスポンスが良い。
Enterを打ち込めば直ぐ様その結果の表示とコマンド待ちになり、その辺のもっさりエフェクトバリバリアクションより余程スタイリッシュに戦える。
チュートリアルが全て終了すると街の様々な施設が利用出来るようになるが、ショートカットが左手に集中しているため慣れれば凄い勢いでリソース回収・戦闘・ビルドが行えるようになる。
超高速でトンカチを弾きながらクーポンを撒き散らしポータルに足を突っ込みながら宿屋を経営できる。

・BGMが素晴らしいの一言に尽きる。
チップチューンをベースとしながらどこかモダンな作りとなっており、通常戦闘曲だけでも10曲用意されている。
文字だらけの世界に非常にマッチしていて、没入感を一層盛り上げてくれる。

・基本はローグライクの流れを汲んでいるのでClassic(ノーマル)難度でも「死んだら終わり」だが、Softcore(イージー)ではデスペナ有りで復活出来る。
死んだら終わるのはイヤだという人も、まずはSoftcoreで死にまくりながらやっていく内にゲームシステムが飲み込めるだろう。
戦闘バランスはClassicと変わらず、更にゲーム内で獲得アイテム率上昇と引き換えに難易度を細かく上げることも出来る。

・ポテトを信仰せよ。

18067459.review:
A comical and surprisingly in-depth RPG that has a lot going for it.  As others have mentioned, this game brings to mind the ASCII multiplayer games like Legend of the Red Dragon, and my favorite, Usurper, that were popular back when Doom II and 56k dial-up connections were cutting edge technology.  But I digress, I'll list the pros and cons I personally found while playing this game, while rating each (+ to +++, - to ---) on how enjoyable or unenjoyable it is:

[b][u][i]Pros[/i][/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Soundtrack[/b] (+++) - The soundtrack for this game is amazing.  The intro theme instantly caught my attention as I started the game for the first, and every subsequent time.  I can't actually name a song that I don't enjoy.  The tavern theme is good, most of the fight and boss songs are also great.  There are piano renditions of the songs available as free DLC which can be found in the game's folder, and they are equally awesome.

[*][b]Gameplay[/b] (++) - The gameplay is highly addictive.  There are so many things to do in addition to the main storyline.  You can mine for ore to make items, read randomly generated library books and hope you get exp, upgrade your home, do side-quests for townsfolk, craft items for a chance at better equipment, fight in an arena, go through randomly generated teleports for harder monsters/better loot, the list goes on.  A lot of the crafting/searching requires energy, which refills as you do normal fights, giving a nice balance of grinding mixed with many other fun side jobs to keep the repetition as minimal as possible.

[*][b]Combat[/b] (++) - Considering you will spend a good portion of your time battling, it's a good thing that combat is for the most part enjoyable, despite the lack of graphics or animations.  In fact, there are many games with graphics and animations that have a less in-depth system than SRPG has.  Typically you will use the 1-4 keys to perform various combos with different moves, in such an order that you are creating combos with a starter move, chain moves, then a finisher.  Each class also has a heal move, and learns other moves such as an ultimate attack, stackable shields, ways to block enemy power attacks, etc.  There is one annoyance I have with combat, but that will be discussed in the cons.

[*][b]Story/Writing[/b] (++) - While I haven't beaten the game, the storyline is fairly generic in terms of plot.  However, the writing is solid and there is quite a bit of humor to the story.  It all begins with the backstory you are given about your character after you create him or her, which is pretty much a randomly generated mad-lib story with random events describing your character, and is pretty amusing most of the time.  This game also loves potatoes for some reason.  You will encounter potatoes as a random event, you will find weapons with "potato" in the name, then you will find items that can boost your weapon if it has "potato" in it's name, which few do.  I give this two +s for having humor and being well-written, despite the aforementioned generic plot.
[/list]
[b][u][i]Cons[/i][/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Combat[/b] (-) - As I mentioned above, combat is a mostly enjoyable experience.  There is, however, quite a bit of grinding that must be done to build up your character.  While this isn't too bad, the personal issue I have with this is that I tend to start spamming attacks fairly quickly (1, enter, 2, enter, 3, enter, 3, enter, check hps, heal or repeat).  95% of the time this works.  The problem with getting into this groove is most monsters have a perk or two from a nice-sized list of perks you can view the effects of by typing "?" into the battle.  You must pay attention to what bonuses your opponents have.  Some of these perks can be devastating, including one that instantly reduces your max HP by 50% for the entire battle (this can be especially bad against bosses that have insane hps, ensuring you will be fighting them for quite some time), or one that constantly drains almost all of your MP/Rage/Ultimate.  I've had monsters with Gigantic (deals major damage to you often) also have the Caustic (player starts with 50% max hps) or Punishing (deals 50% more damage if player is lower than 50% hps) perks, and kill what I felt was a fairly powerful character in 2-3 hits because I wasn't paying attention.  In this game, one death means you have to restart (unless you play Softcore).  I guess if you pay more attention than I do, this won't be an issue, but it's very easy to get into the habit of hitting the same keys over and over.
[/list]

Overall an amazingly fun game.  You can pick it up for a few minutes, or a few hours, and no matter how much or little you do, will feel as if you've improved.  There's a lot I haven't even covered, some of it may be considered spoilers, but there is so much to unlock that won't be directly available to you at the beginning that it gives you even more reason to keep going.

17890662.review:
Sanctuary Plays like a single player MUD.  
If you ever wanted to dip into text based online games but find them intimidating or to rapid paced, this is a much slower, more friendly RPG introduction to ASCII textual adventures.  Set your nostalgia back to the 80s because Sanctuary returns us to the days of IBM floppy disk playstyle, but adds all the swish new techniques of today's slickest MUDs.  
The RPG elements are top notch and more often than not innovative over today's AAA games.  The character class combinations are incredibly fun.  The system is easy enough to understand, so one is never bogged down with endless cumbersome keyboard commands.  The controls make sense, are to the point, displayed on the screen and turn-based, so you can learn at your own pace.  The risk factor makes the game feel very realistic and often even frightening.  Charming townspeople and chilling dungeons alike await intrepid adventurers.  The music is wonderful and worth buying as a DLC.  It evokes feelings of old Nobuo Uematsu fantasies with lots of crunchy nintendo blip goodness.  The graphics may seem simple, but they are incredibly complex and beautiful.  Just try to draw these yourself!  Every monster and treasure is well rendered in ASCII and better than 3D graphics in this case, as it allows the player to imagine a fair amount of the world as well.  
Crafting is great.  Quests are enjoyable.  The fightng is damned fun.  The limit break system is dynamic and carries over across battles.  Stored TP can then be used for difficult battles, opening up with that devastating special attack.  That's just one small example of how complex the battling is.  All the while, it never gets hard to control, overwhelming, or confusing...  but don't go thinking this roguelike holds yer hand, it does not.  The player is soon plunged into a world of danger & excitement.  I fear for my characters' lives.  Their experiences feel very real.
Black Edition is wicked & well polished.  Worth buying again.

10/10 - Better RPG than Skyrim.

(playtime also on Desura & inaccurate)

17500782.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition is a humorous and strategic turn-based dungeon crawling ASCII adventure. Drawing heavy inspiration from both Roguelikes and Japanese RPGs, the game offers a robust action-RPG inspired combat system.

[h1]The Story[/h1]
You know those old B movies you saw at the drive-in, or those old sci-fi flicks that are now in the Public Domain? SanctuaryRPG is like that, and it is meant to be that. It doesn’t try and be some AAA game produced by some ridiculously large studio. No, SanctuaryRPG is a wonderful mess of self-deprecating satire, and that’s what makes it so perfect for a text-based RPG.

[b]Story Verdict[/b]: The precise formula for a comedic, but intriguing, story that’ll keep you enticed.
[b]Story Score[/b]: 9/10

[h1]The Graphics[/h1]
No, I’m not going to tell you that the graphics are terrible because there’s no fancy SSAA or SSAO. SanctuaryRPG relishes in the wonderful world of ASCII art that is detailed and beautiful. Not only that but the game manages to include secrets within the backdrop of symbols that fit naturally. It works, and it works wonderfully!

[b]Graphics Verdict[/b]: Simple and old-school graphics are a throwback to a forgotten era of games.
[b]Graphics Score[/b]: 9/10

[h1]The Controls[/h1]
You can play the whole game with a keyboard, and at no time are controls hidden behind memory. It might take a little time to get used to because of the mechanics, but you are never timed in your decisions. They nailed down solid controls that work well and are always visible.

[b]Controls Verdict[/b]: Simple to use and never hidden.
[b]Controls Score[/b]: 9/10

[h1]The Sounds[/h1]
A myriad of old and newer sounds come together to form the nostalgic, synth-ridden soundtrack of SanctuaryRPG. It’s fun, engaging, and varies enough to keep things fresh during your various adventures. On top of the soundtrack you have the familiar sound effects one would expect from a text-based RPG.

[b]Sounds Verdict[/b]: It’s honestly a really nice soundtrack with some great sound effects to go along with it. It fits well!
[b]Sounds Score[/b]: 8.5/10

[h1]The Difficulty[/h1]
As with any rogue-like game, SanctuaryRPG’s difficulty lies in both skill and learning from your mistakes. It does this quite fairly, and with the right planning one is able to go far without worry of some nonsensical one-hit kill or unfair mechanic. There are always humorous things that can happen against your favour, but I think that’s part of the charm. I found my time with SanctuaryRPG to be balanced and fair, but still always difficult.

[b]Difficulty Verdict[/b]: Just the right amount of reward for just the right amount of saltiness!
[b]Difficulty Score[/b]: 9/10

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
One could say that a single hour of gameplay is not enough to judge the scale of an RPG like this game, but do not be fooled; I have spent many more hours on this game without Steam. I can assure you that SanctuaryRPG is deep and offers such a large variety of gameplay and fun that it’s worth twice the price to me (at least). 

There’s a unique crafting system that is unlike many other RPGs where you have to manage the heat, quality, and durability of an item. You can also run your own tavern; yeah, you can literally become an inn-keeper if you’d like. You can purchase a house too, or fight in the arena!

[b]Replayability Verdict[/b]: More replayability than games asking for over five times as much money!
[b]Replayability Score[/b]: 10/10


[h1]Overall Verdict[/h1]
Huge amounts of gameplay, hilarious story, and engaging graphics give you the most successful nostalgic trip back to the old text-based RPGs of the 80s. I couldn’t recommend this game more, and I consider it one of my favourite RPG games of all time!

[h1]Overall Score: 9.5/10[/h1]

17392711.review:
Antes de mais nada, os disclaimers:

1) SanctuaryRPG é o meu primeiro roguelike. 
2) Ganhei a chave do jogo do usuário do reddit /u/SharpSides, na comunidade /r/RandomActsofGaming, na condição de produzir uma análise honesta.
3) Resenha escrita após mais de 2h de jogo.

[b]Mecânica[/b]
Apesar de estar acostumado com RPGs, gastei pelo menos meia hora para entender a mecânica do jogo. As batalhas são desafiadoras, mas é possível controlar a dificuldade. Permadeath = respeito. Taverna e sistema de residência foram boas surpresas. 

Meu primeiro personagem, um Human Barbarian, Snu, durou seis minutos. Meu terceiro personagem, um Wysperian Ranger, Bob durou uma hora (recorde atual). Não me pergunte do segundo, eu esqueci.

[b]História[/b]
No início parece clichê, mas os toques de humor e nonsense me deixaram. A descrição aleatória da história do seu personagem é hilária. Curioso para chegar ao final do enredo.

[b]Gráficos[/b]
O bom uso de arte ASCII prova que não é preciso ser Skyrim para envolver o jogador no universo do jogo. Por que ver se eu posso imaginar?

[b]Estética[/b]
Acerta o tom do retrô. A trilha sonora é excepcional.

[b]Por que você deveria jogar?[/b]
- Grande homenagem aos roguelikes do passado.
- É um desafio para qualquer gamer.
- É divertido.

[b]Por que você não deveria jogar?[/b]
- Se faz questão de exigir o máximo da sua GPU em todo game.
- Não gosta de ler ou usar a imaginação.

Thankfully you can alter the settings so it doesn't have to be that way. That's a nice addition. Some people will love playing dead is dead, others will pull their hair out... Some will pause write a review and restart, apparently.

Pros
Surprisingly immersive
Combat is easy to grasp
At just over a fiver, you can't argue with the price. You'd not get two pints for that in England. This is way more fun and lasts lots longer.
The graphics are charming and clever for what they are.

Cons
They seems to think that mentioning potatoes is the height of comedy. Unless I'm missing something, I'm inclined to disagree. It borders on immersion breaking tbh, but overall it's a fairly minor complaint.
Combat was beginning to get a bit samey at 4.5 hours.

I'm really enjoying it thus far, and at the price, I already feel I've had my moneys worth from it. Away I go to start afresh.

Pros:

- Awesome combat
- Expansive story
- Lots of humor
- Plenty of content
- Unique look
- Great music

Cons:

- Perma-death

This game is amazing, there is so much to do, some many enemies to fight, and lots of laughs to be had. You will love this game until you are defeated by an enemy and realize you have to start at square one, no matter how much time you have put into your character. I think some games are fine with perma-death, but this game isn't one of those games. SanctuaryRPG is way too big and expansive to have perma-death. I know that there is a softcore mode, but that mode makes it way too easy as their is very little punishment for dying contrary to what the mode description says. I would give this game a 9/10 or maybe even 10/10 if it wasn't for the permanant death. 16968743.review:
Here are just a few reasons why I love this game:

* Gives me flashbacks to old BBS door games and even Sir-Tech's Wizardry, which is a sentimental favorite dungeon crawler.
* I'm a long-time text gamer. Loved MUDs since Kesmai on CompuServe. SanctuaryRPG is the MUD without the occasional aggravation of other people.
* Funny automatically generated back stories for characters.
* Quirky events.
* Lethal boss battles, even at low levels.
* A real sense of distinction between different classes of character.
* The options to play with hardcore permadeath or more forgiving resurrection-style.

It's now my go-to when I need a fun distraction that doesn't call for a lot of computing resources. Great fun!

16846299.review:
I was willing to give this a go, I believe in gameplay over graphics, so an ASCII game does not deter me. I was disappointed by a very flat RPG. Rather than a real RPG with story, real quests and depth, this is more like Legend of the Red Dragon redux, you can perform rote activities. You do not explore the world, instead you either select "combat" or "town", there is no exploration. Quests are accomplished by doing 'combat' until they are fulfilled.
The combat system is the centerpiece of disappointment, with no strategy whatsoever. You do the next sequence in the combat, unless you are hurt enough to require heals, then you heal and continue your combat cycle. I found every combat entirely the same, no enemy made combat feel varied. Perhaps the game has hidden depth, but I did not find any of it.

16838900.review:
This game is the easiest and hardest text advetunre I've ever played. It's easy in the fact that things are pretty straight forward. You don't have to type "Go West" Inspect Object" or figure out the write combination of recognized words to make an action happen. It's very streamlined to pressing certain keys on the board. 

The hard part is surviving and winning. Ugh! It's like 0-60 in a matter of minutes. One minute you're feeling pretty good about defeating enemies and the next you're screaming obsenities because that enemy just killed you even though you had more than half your health, all because it blinded you, froze you, and made it so you could use one attack and oh whoops, that one just so happened to be the one that lets you regain health.

Or maybe I just suck. I dunno. Anyway, it's a fantastic game and you should definitely give it a shot if you're looking for something old but new to play. 

P.S. The music is great, the art is great and I LOVE the randomly generated back story. I've saved every single one. :)

16816262.review: This game is fantastic in so many ways; it's truly a must-have for any RPGer's collection. There's a ton of fun to be had in the world of Sanctuary with a classic and intuitive level grinding system and loots galore! The game strikes a great balance between difficulty and challenge, always keeping you on your toes without sending you to certain death. The ASCII-style UI is super retro, but it's very polished and updated with a modern feel. The humor in this game is outstanding, and quite refreshing to an otherwise serious plotline / series of events. Yes -- one could make the argument that the game lacks depth considering other RPGs we've seen, but that's just it... Sanctuary knows what it is and it does it extremely well without a lot of filler. Your investment in the game is a direct reflection of the progress you'll make, barring any hasty decisions of course. ;) Overall, this masterpiece is well worth your time and money, and I've already sunk in quite a few hours to justify that. 5/5

16691582.review:
Great game to experience, despite its shortcomings.

The ASCII theming is beautiful, and well executed in conjunction with the soundtrack.

There is a lot of fine details and complexities built in to the racial/class selection options. Despite all of them having incredibly similar skillsets, all of their nuances lead to significantly different playstyles.

There are so many different options in combat that result in some complex tactical decisions. With the exception of a few mildly brainless builds or if you significantly overwhelm your opponent, rolling over the same combos against each opponent will not work. There are several probability based status effects or opponent skills that you will need to actively respond to or face the consequences.

Now for my biggest gripe. I am a big fan of the rogue-like and rogue-lite genres. Death can be fun, death is a learning experience, etc. However, it's all relative to the amount of grind that it took to take you up to that death. The first dozen hours or so of SanctuaryRPG are full of so many learning opportunities, that all those many hours spent fighting and crafting weren't a grind at all. But after that point, death becomes frustratingly expensive, because of how many dozens of hours the game can span. This in turn, actually encourages even more grind to the point of getting your character over-leveled for a particular area, as a safety barrier to protect from dying all over again. And there will come fights that completely blindside you from where you completely overwhelmed the previous fight, so there's very little available to signal danger to you until it is far too late.

All that said, though, despite my frustrations with the circumstances surrounding death, learning how to play and experiencing SanctuaryRPG for the first time was a great experience, and frankly a steal at $8.

16668324.review:
SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition, is a masterpiece in it's own right.

30 minutes into the game and I knew I loved it. It's accessible to anyone, and is a game you can marathon on, or to play if you need to kill a bit of time.

This game takes the text-based rpg genre and revives it through interesting/hilarious dialogue, quick and rewarding combat, INCREDIBLE music, and even some exploration! 

A lot of the gripes that people have with this game is that it's a little grindy. I personally don't find that an issue however. The game's quick pace and single button commands make grinding a breeze and even enjoyable at points. Definitely better than any JRPG that you'll ever have to grind for.

10/10

Sanctuary is a throwback to MUDs and Legend of the Green Dragon, you select a "dungeon" location and it rolls an event to happen - 95% of the time it will be a random battle, but there are other events that ask you to interact with something in  some way or just finding a random NPC who says something and gives you experience or even finding an extra temporary dungeon to search through or a hidden boss.   After you're done with whatever you had to do it will throw you back at the base menu ready to go to town or hit up another dungeon.

The combat system is rather indepth and relies upon constantly paying attention to buffs/debuffs and what your enemy is doing so you can try to set yourself up to counter them, all the while trying to maintain a combo which improves the damage of your ultimate skill.  The game rolls out new skills that can allow you to switch up how you fight rather generously over the course of playing your character.

Also, the game will surprise you with it's soundtrack, you just simply aren't expecting it to be as good as it is.

16458197.review:
If you played any door games in the past, such as Trade Wars, Legend of the Red Dragon, Tele-Arena, and various other games played on BBSes, or later MUDs in the beginning of the internet, then do yourself a favor, and buy this right now, you don't need to read further.

I'm such a person.  I played lots of door games, had a BBS myself, and been active on various BBSes for a good number of years, starting with a 2400 baud modem and going all the way up to 56k, then broadband.

I saw SanctuaryRPG suggested to me, and as soon as I saw the store video, saying this was Steam's first ASCII game, and saw the very nice ASCII graphics indeed, I was sold instantly.  I didn't looked up the reviews, nor checked the forums, I didn't even expanded the more info on the game.  I just bought it. 

So when I tried it, I had the biggest surprise of my life... this game is pure genius.  Only with a text game you could come up with such a brilliant, deep, very deep, combat system.   Yeah, you heard me right, this text game has better combat than all graphic games out there.  And yet, you see nothing of the combat itself.  I won't spoil it, but it's real good.

Don't be fooled, its no rogue-like in the common sense, you aren't a letter on a grid, and move one square at a time, with enemy moving after you.  This is played more like traditional door games.  Not MUDs tho.  You don't move with directions.  The rogue part is the permadeath, tho you can play softcore.  But I highly recommend you play the way its intended, classic with permadeath.

The chip tunes soundtrack is very good and totally fit the game.  

I'm currently the owner of a tavern, serve drinks to customers, entertain them by smashing potatos on top of my head, amongst various other things, and sometimes they give me a gift, or leave :)  

Still reading?  Go buy it now!

16443988.review: This game is mondo neat and has top beepboops.

16443753.review:
Do not let the ASCII art turn you off, this game is really amazing. The art is honestly very good for ASCII, and the minimalist style allows for greater focus on the solid combat mechanics that make up the core of the game. As well, you will immediately notice the incredibly high quality chip tune inspired sound track, which is also allowed greater brain share as the graphics are less attention demanding during combat and dialogue.

There are 6 classes which all interact with the basic set of commands available differently. Barbarians heal while doing damage better than other classes, Wizards put up Barriers that increase their defense and offense, Rangers shoot and stab things to death while nimbly avoiding damage, etc...

On top of this, there is a vibrant meta-game layer in which you can own a bar, build a house, become a master crafter of various items (this system is VERY well done), go to the Colosseum and use the Arena (fight for crafting materials), explore Portals (fight for great loot), and do Ranked Matchmaking (fight for Skill points).

If you can deal with perma-death, this game should not be passed up. Fights tend to be fair and you will realize quickly what you're doing wrong after the first few deaths. It does have a mode where death is not permanent as well, though, if that is really a deal breaker for you.

11/10 Potatos

15835831.review:
终于完成了一周目，感觉有底气写评测了。

大部分人看评测还是想知道值不值得买吧？在这个问题上，我推荐。即使不打折也是值的。而且这游戏目前节操还算硬，没有见过有大的促销。

如果你觉得游戏画面无所谓，那么这款游戏的前 10 小时的体验就没有太多缺点了。况且、Ascii ART 超萌有没有？图像就是为了让你轻松的接收游戏想传达给你的信息，让你不那么费力的看文字。这款游戏的图像其实做到了这一点。

游戏的文字界面简洁有力，虽然英文不好的我经常需要去查查字典，但也没觉得特别的语言障碍。游戏的战斗系统和锻造系统都还不错，还有许多小系统供你发掘，当开发者的精力不放在建模精美的 3d 世界上时，总会花在另一些有价值的地方吧。

这是个幽默的游戏，初见基本材料灵魂石是块显卡的时候笑死我了。然后第一次介绍系统时来了个红字警报：此处有大量文字（其实也不多啦），感觉的到开发者的幽默感。

表面上你会觉得游戏的感觉像 MUD ，其实不是的。我不是 MUD 的粉丝，稍微玩过一点而已。这款更接近它名字所说的 RPG 类型。故事性还是不错的，当然你要有耐心读，留意里面的小细节。如果不关心剧情的话，就当是一个回合制的紧张刺激，有各种装备掉落的 loot 游戏玩就好了。主线够你玩接近 20 小时的。

一开始会觉得比较虐，我连死了 7,8 次才大致明白怎么不死。永久死亡的设定让每场 boss 战都变的刺激。不过普通难度还是满贴心的，其实把握好度， 2 小时后你就不那么容易死掉了，反正可以逃嘛，别贪心就成。

----

不过，进入 Act4 后有点无聊。感觉重复性比较高。那是 10 多小时之后的事情了。现在让我 2 周目我暂时还没有立刻开始的冲动。

ps. 音乐真心不错。

15707723.review:
Here is the short and sweet: This is a surpisingly enjoyable game. Buy it.

- SanctuaryRPG is RPG in its core form. You get right at the stats, drops, and builds that makes RPG... RPG. No fancy UI interfaces get in the way. It is in the title of the game. RPG. RPG. RPG.

- Feature to turn off dialog exists if you find it too annoying.

- It is text, it takes seconds to get in to battle from startup. This makes it perfect for both casual and in-depth gaming sessions.

- You die, game over. Each battle plays out in different ways. Working several hours on a toon to only die because you didn't pay attention in battle... sucks! (You can turn off perma-death if you want. It is more exciting with it on, and the drops are better. Recommend you do classic to start with.)

- Pacing is up to you. Play casual or play hardcore.

This game isn't perfect, but the downsides are so minor there is no reason to mention them.

15694758.review:
A damn fine game. I'd call this the true evolution to classic computer text adventures. It's just loaded with so much to do and it presents those things to you a little at a time so you don't feel overwhelmed at the start. Not to mention the music is absolutely stellar. It couldn't possibly be any more fitting. 
The battle system is really interesting. In most RPG's your best tactic is to just use your best spell or ability and spam attacks until the enemy is dead. This game is different in that you have several meters you need to keep track of and you're given a multitude of special attacks to perform to either ramp up your meters or spend it all on devastating blows. You use certain attacks in a sequence to unleash combos, filling up your meters, your health bar, and laying down the hurt at the same time. You're given multiple combos you can perform, each having their own uses. You will also need to keep track of when you need to shift spots or defend. The enemy telegraphs charging attacks, giving you enough turns to ramp up your defense or get ready with heals. They can also leave your guard wide open, forcing you to reposition to gain footing and get your defense back. These are just the standard methods of battling for all classes. Each class gets extra abilities to go along with this to compliment all their playstyles. Seems like a lot but it's something you get used to quickly. The game is especially good at dishing you new things in small doses to make sure everything you learn sticks and you don't get overwhelmed with knowledge. A great example of teaching a player how to play your game that every game developer should practice.
The people making this game are very, very talented. Show them some support, do yourselves a favor and get this game. If you love a good, hardcore RPG then this game is definitely for you.

15694308.review:
Okay, first off I am old.  I admit it.  I was big in bulletin boards back in the 80s and early 90s before the Web took off. Back there there were a number of BBS games like Legend of the Red Dragon (LoRD) that I spent countless hours playing online (I used online in jest as it was a dial-up to another PC, or sometimes my own BBS that I ran.  Anyway early text based RPGs used to be the thing back then.  You had to use this little thing called imagination that most gamers don't exercise much these days.   Where am I going with all this?  Well SanctuaryRPG returns me to those days.  Days when I would have a blast just hititng a few keys and enjoying the ride.   SanctuaryRPG is very enjoyable so far to me.  I haven't spent a ton of time playing yet, just 2.5 hours but I have had a blast during that time.  

Don't let the ASCII graphics fool you, they are done with amazing detail.  The game play is what matters here though. You will be scratching for just one more turn.  Dont' say I didn't warn you.

15133259.review:
[h1]I don't think I would have purchased this had I realized it's a casual game.[/h1]
 As of the writing of this review "SanctuaryRPG:Black Edition"  isn't quite any of the things I look for in an RL game.  I'd wanted a first person roguelike-dungeon crawl, sort of an ascii version of "Dungeon Master". But , I got a passable knock-off of the old door-game "Legend Of the Red Dragon" .       

 The crafting system is easy to understand, Stupidly-so, It only has two or three component parts and you can't experiment at all. For examples of fun/interesting crafting systems; take a look at the RL "Cataclysm:DDA" or "Arcanum"  or more recent examples in the "Witcher" and recent Elder Scrolls and Fallout games.  The whole thing feels like it was somebody's programming midterm project, and they coded the easy stuff first and just slapped in place holder code for the rest. 

I hope that someday this game will suprise me by becoming what I'd hoped to purchase.

*revised july 2015

15098234.review:
[b][i]Sanctuary RPG Black Edition[/i] gets my vote for Best Overall Game of the Year 2015.[/b]

Gosh dang this is a good game!! Has some [i]real[/i] depth, and [i]excellent[/i] artwork. Way to go guys, this is how indie game making is done. I mean its hard to come up with cons.

[b]Pros:[/b]
1. Utterly addictive
2. You only need the keyboard, and the controls are pure butter - so intuitive
3. Crafting, base-building, taver-running, fighting, leveling up, arenas, and economy,  lore, etc. and its all really well done
4. Little secrets here and there, you will be learning things for a while - and its fairly easy to pick up
5. The roguelike feature is AWESOME because you have so much at stake for your character
6. Music is really a good fit, and quite well done

[b]Cons:[/b]
1. I honestly cannot think of any - please comment about negative things and I may change my mind

So much fun.

[b]La recensione completa su Kingdomgame.it:[/b] 

http://www.kingdomgame.it/recensione/8470-sanctuaryrpg-black-edition-recensione-retro-in-codice-ascii

SanctuaryRPG è senza dubbio un buon titolo. Giocandoci si nota subito il grande lavoro che Black Shell Games ha dedicato nel costruire tutte le creature e i paesaggi semplicemente in codice ASCII ma sopratutto per realizzare un combat system profondo. 

Di sicuro i videogiocatori più datati, che hanno vissuto gli anni d'oro di questo genere, non dovrebbero lasciarselo sfuggire, ma lo stesso non si può dire per i videogiocatori più giovani e neofiti al genere. 

Questi ultimi troveranno non poche difficoltà giocando questo titolo che si discosta nettamente dai giochi più moderni e ai quali siamo abituati. In qualunque caso questo titolo saprà farvi ridere con la sua ironia, ammaliarvi con le sue musiche e offrirvi una buona dose di sfida con i suoi combattimenti.

14674358.review:
I really wanted to like this game.

I've been playing Roguelikes since the late 80s. I love the format and am willing to accept a lot of drawbacks for a good, immersive Roguelike experience. I even put 150 hours into Rogue's Tale, an unfair and punishing Roguelike solely due to how challenging it was. 

SanctuaryRPG isn't really a Roguelike, as much as it likes to say it is. It's really just a loot grind. 

 Is the loot I just found/made better than what I have? 
 Yes? Equip it. Scrap old item to get more materials to craft loot.
 No? Scrap it. Get more materials to craft loot. 
 Repeat Forever

The Town Hub could have been a neat idea, but it's too static. Nothing really changes. Go to the Blacksmith every so often to look at more gear. Go to the Market if you need a missing material. Go to the Library for a bit of exp every so often. Go to the campground to dig for loot...

Basically, between the loot grind, go visit each place in the town hub for more loot or exp. Go back and fight random encounters. Repeat forever.

Now, I say forever, but this is where the biggest fundamental flaw of SanctuaryRPG lies: The game is ridiculously easy in such a way that you play on autopilot until you realize you accidentally died because you've been playing on autopilot and you now have to start over. 

Sure, you can crank the combat difficulty up, but that doesn't seem to do much. 

The combat system is a neat idea and really the only interesting thing SanctuaryRPG brings to the table. There's a combo system and ability system that's pretty interesting. Big points for that piece. But the rest of the game doesn't do anything new or interesting.

One of the other flaws in the game is that the ramp up, for a roguelike with permadeath, is way too long. I played 2 sessions of this game, both times into Act 2 before autopilot-mistake killed me about 3 hours in. That's way too long for the "introduction" period for a Roguelike. You can take off Permadeath to negate this, however, if you don't play with Permadeath some features of the game are locked down and progression is even slower.

The story is awful and the humor is just referential. If you're a fan of when a game says, "Hey, look! The cake is a lie! We just made a reference! Aren't we funny and edgy?!", then you'll enjoy the humor in this game.

I wish you could rate a "meh" as opposed to up or down, but I really can't recommend this game. 

Tl; dr: Diablo-Style loot grind on Hardcore mode that's so ridiculously easy you'll mindlessly autopilot the game until something instagibs you because you weren't paying 100% attention.

How is that fun?

14649943.review:
What if you could take the sensibilities of an old-school text-based game like Zork and place them inside the body of a modern roguelike game? You'd probably end up with SanctuaryRPG, an addictive adventure game that casts you as the next great hope to stop a powerful enemy named The Matron.

Along the way, you'll encounter enemies ranging from simple skeletons to punishingly tough boss monsters. You'll perhaps take over the local tavern and shake your moneymaker for gifts. Your simple little campground can be upgraded into a crafting haven for making the shiniest of gear. And all of it (and more) will happen in front of a wall of ASCII art that cleverly rewards careful attention to detail with hidden secrets at the press of the correct button at the right time.

In short - this game is incredible. Buy it.

The incredible ASCII-style art brings me back to simpler times when I would visit my babushka in the old village of Nikolaevka. The combat system is dynamic and your enemies are ruthless. Overall, this game is more than worth its price, but I'd rather have you give that money to me instead; 8.5/10.

14564298.review:
The silly cousin of Diablo made with ascii art and a epic soundtrack.
That sounds pretty awesome and trust me, it is!

SanctuaryRPG is a game envisioned and programmed by a single person. You start of this game creating a character. Selecting between various races/classes/weapon styles and more. After that you'll select between hardcore mode (die once and you lose your character) or casual mode. Then your adventure starts into this wacky ascii world filled with enemy encounters, silly dialogue and lot of random loot. Just like in Diablo you will get that feeling of glee when you find another epic or even legendary piece of equipment.

Graphicly the game is .. text based. I grew up past the whole textbased era of games but for it only being text it looks good. For me it doesn't add or detract anything to the game.

The music is a great feature of this game. Every tune just fits the scene. For example the blacksmith theme has a blacksmith hammer clanging with the tune and it sounds awesome. There are a lot of various battle themes (all of them sound great) which is important because you will be battling 80% of your time in the game.

One of the things I disliked about the game was how you lose all progress when you die. Ofcourse that's normal in a roguelike game, but deaths can be very random and the game isn't short. I got past act 1 on a 2,5 hour play session, was feeling very strong only to die by a random encounter. After you restart you get the slow unlocking of abilities and story arc again and they are the same every time, so that can get a bit tedious.

I haven't finished the game yet, don't know if I ever will (random stuff can and will kill you eventually, it seems) but what I have played so far is a lot of fun and I can feel the passion that creators have put into this project.

14547852.review:
This game is a great rouge-like, it doesn't have fancy graphics or orchestral music but it has what it needs to have. ASCII style artwork is the best I've seen so far and the music isn't bothersome even if it is repetitive. The game's real success lies in its comedic work and the rouge-like systems. You will fail and you will do so miserably but it is a blast while it lasts. 

There's also a soft-core mode for people who don't like rogue-like games. You can just respawn and keep playing.

14545812.review:
Diablo meets NetHack. 6 classes to choose from (with many ways to customize them), randomized loot and events, a long story mode and a number of sidequests, like managing a tavern, fighting in the colosseum and crafting items (including a neat forging mini-game).

Being an ASCII game has the advantage that it plays as fast as your fingers. Once you're familiar with the commands you can finish fights and visit locations in an instant. You almost play the game on automatic at this point. There's no time wasted watching long attack animations or walking everywhere.

On top of it all there's the great 8-bit soundtrack and the wacky humor. During one random event I found a sleeping man and was asked if I wanted to whack him in the face with a stick or defecate on him.

Game's also pretty challenging. Permadeath is present here and you can lose many hours of playtime because you were playing absent-mindedly. There's a softcore mode with no permadeath but that's not how the game is meant to be played.

My only complaint is that the game can feel grindy. Often you'll unlock a new area but you're still underleveled to face it, so you need to grind levels in previously cleared areas or risk losing your character to strong enemies.

In any case, a solid game. 10/10 would defecate on sleeping man again.

14543386.review: A very good RPG with a very nostalgic feel to it. If you like games like Zork, you will love this.

14540204.review:
A really awesome trip to the past!  

I used to play text adventures back in the 80's and early 90's and SanctuaryRPG really brings me back.

 Sanctuary pays homage to a time when these great games totally relied on your imagination and that alone.

The game is extremely deep and there is a massive amount of depth in character and weapon customization.  The best way to play is classic (permadeath).  I find that if you play with respawning enabled, the game just isn't as fun.

SanctuaryRPG has a really great soundtrack as well!  Lots of text games didn't have soundtracks and it really adds to the experience. 

A glorious return to the days of Zork, Adventure, Jigsaw and more.  There really is a lot more going on in SanctuaryRPG than any of these older games, the massive amount of depth is actually quite impressive.   

A quality experience for sure!  Great work guys.

14538187.review:
NOTE: I immediatly wrote this review after my first Playthrough of the game so I have not experienced much.

I had read about this previously (before steam release) in PC gamer and I thought I would love it as I do like me some classic Rogue or Stone Soup and I was right.

You dont have a top down view of where you are and move around with strange keyboard controls like most ASCII RL games. It plays more like an interactive text game (like zork for example) but with less freedom and knowing where you're going more instead of spamming north until something interesting happens or waiting whilst thorin starts singing about gold.

The combat system looks really complicated and it is, you have starting moves, linking moves and finishing moves. You're meant to use a starter then a linking move and then a finisher unlocks which you can use for extra damage or something. there is also relocating so if an enemy is about to charge you or something then you can relocate and the enemys charge cancels. There are also rage attacks but I have no idea how it works.

This game is packed with references to fantasy/Sci-FI films and games Like the lord of the rings, the game also seems to have an unhealthy obsession with potatoes (seriously the second weapon I picked up was a potatoe staff). and the game makes me laugh in normal conversation with the NPC's saying stupid things or breaking the fourth wall. Once during some "Mountain Exploration" I came across some "Random Onions" and my options were 1) boil 'em 2) mash 'em 3) sitck 'em in a stew Which was a hilarious nod to lord of the rings (well I found it pretty funny at least).

The soundtrack is pretty good and it made me feel weird actualy like I was tripping out or something and I couldn't help feeling disconnected from everything but the game immersing me in its rather ridiculous world.

The ASCII art of the different characters is really good too even on the enemies the same jumbled letters, numbers and symbols put together are different each time and I even saw a skeleton that looks like Megadeths mascot "Vic Rattlehead" although I don't know if that was intentional (Megadeth is a Thrash Metal band that was famous throughout the 80's and 90's). 

Overall the game is really good although i'm probably biased because i'm a sucker for roguelikes.

I score the game a solid 9/10 If you like good storytelling and strange monty python/deadpool humor then this is a must buy.

14538159.review:
游戏小不代表不好玩、这款游戏完美的诠释了这句话！
这款游戏让我想到了当年的mud游戏、可能是我年龄的问题，我接触mud 的时候，几乎已经没什么人在玩了。就各种下单机版的mud、一个人摸索着玩。那段快乐的日子再也找不到了。
=============================================================================
接下来给个简单的入门翻译吧、方便下英文苦手们、同时也是抛砖引玉、希望有大神发下自己的攻略。
首先是游戏界面、一进去会给你4个选项，1是开始游戏2是设置3是成就4是工作人员名单。直接按1然后确认进入游戏就好。
进入游戏后，会出现6个选项，这个选择的是职业，1是野蛮人2是圣骑士3是刺客4是法师5是德鲁伊6是游侠
选择好自己的职业后，会提示你是否需要view detailed perks、查看详细的意思。自己随意选（其实是我看不太懂咦嘻嘻嘻嘻）
接下来会让你选择性别，1、male（男性）2、female（女性）3、other（其他、、、、、、这又是什么鬼）
选好性别之后呢。会让你选择body type（体形），1、tiny（较小）2、thin（瘦弱）3、medium（中等）4、muscular（强壮）5、thick（粗壮）这个具体我还不造有啥影响。看心情选吧
选好体形后。会让你取名字。直接输入后按enter就好。然后就能进游戏开始玩耍了、have fun~~
（攻略未完待续）
=============================================================================
希望这款游戏能走的更远。
谨以此游戏纪念逝去的那段时光

14536270.review:
재미있다.여타 로그라이크처럼 무자비하지 않은게 장점.
소프트코어 모드를 하면 죽어도 돈과 경험치만 제로가 될 뿐 레벨은 그대로 남고 돈도 후반엔 차고 넘친다.
소프트코어를 다 클리어하면 노멀,루나틱 순으로 가는데 (죽으면 데이터 삭제)
아무래도 게임자체의 플레이 타임이 길다보니 난이도가 높다.

장점을 꼽자면 캐릭터의 성장 방법이 무궁무진 하다는 점.
그리고 아이템을 파밍하는 재미도 한 몫 한다.
그런데 역으로 한 가지 문제인 것이 , 아이템을 수제작 할 때 공을 들이면 그만큼의 댓가가 있어야하는데
아무리 시간을 써가며 만들어도 장비의 주요 목적인 스탯에는 전혀 영향이 없고, 사실상 별 필요없는 방어력이 조금 오를 뿐이다.
이 부분은 조금 개선이 되어야 한다고 생각한다.

게임 특성상 플레이타임은 길지만 내용이 조금 부실한 상황이 발생한다
실제로도 플레이하며 '이야기가 벌써 끝난건가?' 라는 생각을 했었다.
처음 끝을 보는데에 6시간 정도 소요했는데, 그 다음부터는 난이도만 높아질 뿐 달라지는 것이 없었다.
라이트하게 즐기기 위해 소프트코어만 진행했고, 최고레벨을 달성하고 소프트코어의 모든 난이도(인페르노++)까지 클리어 하는데에 23시간이라는 플레이타임이 기록되었다.
만약 게임내에 따로 난이도가 존재하지 않았다면 나는 6시간만에 소프트코어 난이도를 끝마치고 종료했을 것이다.

그래도 이 정도 금액으로 구매해 최소 20시간정도의 플레이타임은 보장되는 셈이고(플레이 방식에 따라 달라진다)
좀 더 하드하게 즐기고 싶다면 나머지 2개의 난이도를 클리어 하는 것도 괜찮다고 생각하여 한 번쯤 권해보는 게임이다

14516561.review:
INTRO
Sanctuary was an impulse buy for me because I have a weakness for ASCII art and keyboard controlled games. Like many of my Steam purchases, I was fully prepared for this to entertain me for a single play session and to be quickly forgotten. I was not prepared for how immediately engaging this game would be.

DIFFICULTY
I continually feel rewarded by the frequent leveling and item drops. I was never in any doubt that my character was growing increasingly more powerful with every action taken, and I've never felt the need to grind levels or gear. Despite this being true across my playthroughs, the game never allows me to be careless. Any encounter could easily result in my death which, in Classic mode, is permanent. For me, there is a perfect balance between reward and challenge in this game.

GAMEPLAY
In addition to advancing the story, there are various side tasks that can be performed often, but not constantly, including crafting, management, fetch quests, and battles. I did not ignore any of these since they provide experience and offer a nice diversion. I'm not sure if the core gameplay might become a bit monotonous if I ignored all of these side tasks.

LENGTH
I have not succeeded in beating the game yet, but I'd estimate that an average, successful playthrough would take 2-4 hours depending on familiarity with the game mechanics and progression. Keep in mind though that this estimate is based on the assumption that I've made it to the final encounter of the game.

STORY & WRITING
It's too soon for me to accurately say, but the story seems to be entirely linear. This could be considered a negative to some due to the game's length and permadeath feature. A softcore game type is option, but this seems to prevent unlocking some game options. In my opinion though, the story is very well written and there likely would have been a quality drop if it had been branching or randomized. The flavor text that is included with battles and other interactions has been entertaining and varied enough to me to keep me looking forward to reading it.

SOUND
I appreciate the retro-inspiration and found the music to be very, very enjoyable. Sound effects are about what I expected, though there are situations where a battle end sound effect seems to be missing, which briefly takes me out of the experience.

REPLAYABILITY & VALUE
Once I beat the game, I'm not sure if I will immediately start playing with a new class or if I will move on to another game, but I know that I'll have enjoyed every hour spent during that playthrough and would gladly pay $7.99 again if I had to do it over.

Update on game length: I completed Act 3 in about 3.5 hours as a Barbarian. I assumed this would be the end of the game. There is an Act 4, but it felt more like post-game than a continuation. I, admittedly, did not live much longer though, so it's possible that I just didn't progress the story yet. I ended up dying during "Ranked Matchmaking" at the Colosseum.

14499860.review:
[h1]tl;dr - This is an exceptional game[/h1]

Around about a year ago the 'original' SanctuaryRPG was released.  I downloaded it back then (it is freeware) and fell in love with it.  Black Edition (paid now) adds more content, better art, more races, more class perks, mercenaries, faction system, etc.

This is a turn-based rogue-like RPG with surprisingly deep content.  Combat requires you to always pay attention.  Is the enemy getting ready to charge you?  Are you snared?  What sort of special modifiers does this enemy have?  What debuffs have I got & can I get rid of them (is it worth it)?

There's a few different places for combat to take place, too.  You can just be out in the fields encountering enemies, pressing forward with the story, in one of the 'randomly generated' dungeons from the Colloseum or taking part in ranked matches in the colloseum.  I'm not really far into this edition, so there might be more later.. Who knows.

Besides combat there are other things to do!  You can take over a bar and serve the patrons to try and get gifts, spend cash to upgrade it & draw more patrons, get cheaper beer, etc.  There's a sort-of house building mechanic where you can gradually upgrade your camping ground to a hut, shack, cabin, etc.  A great crafting system that reminds me of the system in Final Fantasy XIV.  Plenty of amusing 'events' that take place!  See a syringe on the ground?  Yes, you have the option of picking it up and injecting yourself.  Come across a cow?  You can kiss that thing.

The caveat of this game is that it is entirely text.  All the art is ASCII art (and it's great) - this means it's definitely not for everyone, but I HIGHLY recommend everyone at least give the freeware version a shot (this might just be a demo now.. Google for it), and if you like it.. Pick up the Black Edition.

I highly recommend this game, but am willing to admit that it is probably not for the majority of gamers.

14494847.review:
SUMMARY:  Must-buy for RPG fans.  An easy-to-play, surprisingly complex and deep humorous RPG with a retro text-graphic aesthetic.  A bargain at the price, it provides plenty of challenge delivered with humor.

SanctualyRPG is probably best summed up as "far more than it seems."

At first it seems like an attempt to do a retro RPG, with graphics consisting entirely of text characters and simple controls and character management.  Very quickly you realize this game is the very summary of "more than the sum of its parts."

Characters?  Well you pick a class and races, and then level up various attributes and skills.  However the traits, the attributes and skills you chose, have a variety of effects in game.  They're even more pronounced when combined with equipment.

That Equiment?  There's armor, shields, charms, and a variety of weapons with assorted randomized traits and stat boosts.  You're never quite sure what you're going to find or make, and surprises abound.

Crafting?  Oh, you'll get plenty of that.   You'll collect and salvage various resources to make weapons, armor, and more.  You even unlock more crafting options over time, giving you more to do back at camp.

Camp?  You get a camp to start with, and are able to upgrade your home, mine, and of course make items.  When you're done you can leave to visit other areas in Sanctuary.

These other Areas provide plenty to do, from shopping to visiting a library to fighting in an Arena or in procedural dungeons.  They even have a few surprises.

Oh and there's actually a story behind all this.  Often silly and loaded with potatoes, sometimes gruesome and sad, and always driving you forward.  It even comes in acts so you know how far along you are.

This, you'll note, is even before you get to adventuring.

Adventuring is pretty simple - go to an area, something random happens, and occasionally a secret area or exploration option will appear.  Youi'll usually meet monsters, but also can find yourself accomplishing various silly tasks or finding treasure.  Though you may have to climb a statue or dance with a golem to get it.

Combat is a combo-based and status-effect based system.  Building combos unlocks more attacks, and status effects can provide vital differences.  You can build up powerful attacks, and acquire more and more abilities over time.  Juggling them in proper order - and the proper sequence to handle various enemies - is of utmost importance.   You have to pay attention to a variety of factors, and most combats are pretty involving as your HP, statuses, and MP fluctuate with choices.

On top of all of this there's different difficulty levels and unlockables, so the more you play, the more there is to do.

The entire package is a fun, addictive, clever game that I'd have happily paid twice the price for.  If you like good RPGs, want one you can play for a few minutes or for hours, and have a sense of humor, go for it.  Buy it.

Take a potato.  Trust me.
