14492861.review:
I'm really torn on recommending or not recommending the game.

It is a great game that simply shouldn't be a rogue-like. Deep combat, huge amount of RPG goodness like classes, crafting, customization, skills, discovery, exploration, and a deep narrative. So much to do. So much love in this game and the DOS-like interface is hardly noticeable. The game is very, very immersive and you grow attached to you characters. The game is deceptiely deep.. literally not one dull moment.

There is a lot of content in the game. A full playthrough could easily go 10-15 hours.

Therein lies the crappy part - this game is a 1-death permadeath roguelike. Some enemies are very very strong and sort of "come out of nowhere"  and two-shot you (often after a wave of trivial fights). Your characters die rather... unceremoniously... and you get nothing from their deaths.  It's not like other roguelikes where the game is short enough to where it's alright, or you have sort of an "HQ" through which dying at least allowed some sort of gain... you start from square one. 

There is a "softcore" mode... but each death in this mode reduces global item drop rates. That just isn't fun. So much of the game is collecting items and managing them... not an inspiring or fun way to play the game. I don't count that as a decent softcore mode - each time you die the game becomes less fun and more tedious.

EDIT: I WAS WRONG ABOUT SOFTCORE MODE! Each death DOES NOT drop global drop rates. Rather, global drop rates are dropped just once.. at the beginning of the game. Not as harsh. THAT SAID - the reduced item drop rate still is a "punishment" mechanic for choosing an easier difficulty. Further, softcore mode just feels... lame. You die and instantly come back and can enter that exact same fight with a single keypress. In other RPGs with a save system, you at least have to "go through the dungeon" or something similar. There are some stakes on the line for dying - you'll have to climb to the top of the mountain, or whatever. Softcore mode removes the stakes entirely. The game has two extremes - a completely inappropriate die-and-restart-the-entire-15-hour-game, or absolute-0-consequence-for-dying. Neither are compelling to me as a player. Game would be perfect with a Final Fantasy style in-between.

Also, I know people say "yeah, hard perma-death... that's the fun! that's the point". But I don't know. It doesn't feel right for this game. It's so deep... there is so much joy just from the RPG elements. The game replays every narrative scene on playthroughs.... you slowly unlock gameplay elements EACH playthrough... it's like the game wasn't MEANT to be a roguelike. You end up banging the spacebar through story sequences you've already seen. You end up saltily unlocking skills and gameplay elements that you already have intimate knowledge of ("You've unlocked crafting - here's hw you craft" after having been a craftmaster last playthrough). I feel like the developer jumped on the roguelike train on a game that didn't need to be a roguelike.

The result of the harsh roguelike set-up with a simply ANNOYING and UN-FUN result is that you grind grind grind to make sure you don't die to an encounter that catches you off-guard. You make your character OP. Still, you may die to a surprise insanely powerful enemy... but maybe not.

All this bad stuff said - the game is great fun. Well worth 5 dollars. ESPECIALLY if you like challenging rogue-likes and are slightly masochistic... GET THIS GAME. If you just want a great RPG... maybe look elsewhere. This game will frustrate you for being a great RPG that deletes your save when you die.

3/5 (5/5 if not a rogue-like)

14490449.review:
Downloaded the demo for this thinking, "Oh it's yet another dungeon-crawling roguelike. I'll try it out but I'm sure I'll get bored of it soon." After nearly 5 hours of playtime on just the demo, I grudgingly (and happily) have to admit that I couldn't be more wrong. This is an interesting and excellent game that reminds me of what would happen if Zork, Aniwey's CandyBox, and Kingdom of Loathing made a freaky three-way lovechild that has a bizarre obsession with potatoes.


PROS
+ Fun and engaging retro-esque gameplay
+ Demands your attention during battle, unlike a lot of turn-based RPGs where you can just autoattack your way to victory
+ Quirky and goofy sense of humor
+ Really good music
+ Potatoes

WASHES
= Challenging and punishing, like most roguelikes seem to be. I find this enjoyable personally but be warned!
= ASCII graphics. I don't mind much personally since they're fairly well done, but YMMV.

CONS
- Heavy RNG reliance and it often bites you in the butt (example: I'm playing a Paladin. One of the class "perks" is you deal 25% less damage unless you have a Heavy shield. After about 2 hours into the game, I've found dozens of Light and Medium shields but no Heavy!)
- Pretty dense information-wise, definitely has a bit of a learning curve. Doesn't help that the official wiki is pretty sparse on some details.


On the whole: Extremely engaging for any dungeon crawler looking to delve back into the "good old days" with a little text-based romp. Very, very good for the price.

14489997.review:
[b]If you're like me, you hate ASCII.[/b]

Having grown up in the 90's, I was spoiled on 16-bit graphics, and later, polygons. I didn't even know ASCII was a thing until I started getting into roguelikes in my teens, and even then, I had to use tilesets for games like Rogue and Nethack just to comprehend what I was seeing. Some games, like Dwarf Fortress, have remained arcane to me even after hours of video tutorials. In short, ASCII graphics were something I either liked games [i]in spite[/i] of, or an obstacle that prevented me from enjoying games I'd otherwise like.

Days ago I'd have laughed in your face for suggesting I'd be charmed by this graphical style one day... Particularly because years of struggling with it had made me bitter. It had become a sign of desperation to me in modern indie games; the last bastion for a dev team short on artistic talent. I saw it as an easy out. A flaw. A design choice always made when the pressures of time, money, or ambition precluded other, better graphical styles.

[b]And then I played SanctuaryRPG... And my world changed.[/b]

SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition is a turn-based tactical RPG with, as you've probably guessed, ASCII graphics. Naturally this means that most screens in the game are represented by text, (usually white) on a black background. It's my opinion that this is innately annoying to look at for hours at a time, but SanctuaryRPG have made several smart design decisions that make it tolerable, (at the very least) even to the harshest detractors of text-based graphics. 

For one thing, ASCII games are notorious for often being visually cluttered. In some genres, like grand strategy, this is practically unavoidable. But SanctuaryRPG, being predominantly a turn-based, menu-heavy RPG, includes a great deal of negative space in every screen. Even better, most of the time the positive space is taken up by nothing more than competent, charming, and not at all visually taxing ASCII illustrations that vary in colour, plus the omnipresent menus beneath them.

Obviously if you're not a fan of turn-based RPGs the menus can be a turn off, but as someone with a bit of experience in the genre I can say with confidence that SanctuaryRPG's menus are quite easy to understand and navigate. And when they're not, you can type a question mark in most screens of the game for some clarification. Also, and this is kind of a weird observation, the devs take a great deal of care in not forcing you to remember your character's details. Usually if you can take an action that draws on your character's traits, the game will inform you of the relevant trait in parentheses at the end of the option you can select to perform that action. You'll rarely have to look at your character sheet in-depth, making gameplay much more kinetic and less prep-heavy than it otherwise would be.

Now, I know I've gone on about the graphical style of the game quite a bit... But if I do, it's only because I know how skeptical I was before purchasing - and I want to bully other skeptics into doing the same. Because underneath its divisive ASCII exterior lies a truly fun and fulfilling RPG. It doesn't just set up the main quest and inexolerably push you toward its conclusion; it gives you [i]options[/i]. You can engage in random events, fight in an arena, dig for minerals, craft equipment, fight sets of procedurally-generated enemies, do sidequests, join factions, have awkward conversations with NPCs, run a bar, improve your camp, read books, be followed home by a potato, and more! And some of the minigames associated with these activities are surprisingly robust. 

Unfortunately, this wouldn't be a review without outlining some things I take issue with in the game; thankfully none of them are too bad. For one, even after the tutorial I found conducting combat a little confusing. Some of the less traditional RPG battle concepts, like moveset swapping, knowing when to heal and when to finish a combo, fully understading your meters, and the *HUGE* list of enemy traits are hard to get down at first, and the subtleties kind of have to be arrived at through trial and error. Also, there are no combat animations or anything, so tossing a fireball as a mage is about as visually interesting as swinging a sword; which is to say, not. Thankfully the classes are differentiated greatly by their traits, so it's still very worthwhile to try on different hats... Not that you'll have much of a choice playing in classic mode, because you're almost certainly going to die, and will NOT want to level that barbarian up to 20 again.

So, in closing, I would say that SanctuaryRPG is not only a great game, but the only one to ever cure me, (if only temporarily) of my bias against ASCII graphics. If that's your last sticking point when it comes to buying this game, at [i]least[/i] try the demo, (available on the developer's site) and see if you enjoy the gameplay. If you typically enjoy challenging turn-based RPGs with a great deal of content outside of the main storyline, this may just be the game for you. If you like all that and don't mind harsh penalties for character death, this is almost certainly the game for you. But don't take my word for it; research! Do enough digging and you'll find the lovely, impassioned devs behind it all, who clearly believe in their product and have infused it with quality to match. And if that isn't the best argument for taking a chance on this game, I don't know what is!

Oh, and did I mention that the game is chock-full of oddball humour? Didn't feel right to list it with the pros or the cons since it's such a subjective thing. I like it, though. :)

14481774.review:
Pros:
- Very nice fighting system: you can't just spam your preferred skill until the enemy is dead, but you have to actively respond to his attacks and pay attention to his bonus stats.
- Has a lot of humour in it. (a lot of potatoes as well)
- The music really fits with the ASCII-images
- This game proves that flashy graphics are not needed for a good game. 
- You're not just limited to fighting enemies, but you can also craft, run a tavern, dance naked and do unmentionable things to potatoes.
- Exploring all of your options is rewarded.

Cons:
- The game can sometimes get grindy: all of a sudden you'll need X items to progress the main story.
- What I really miss in this game is some sort of backpack, no matter how limited. Most of the time it is pretty clear whether you should keep your current item or replace it by a new one, but in some cases (like with weapons that do extra damage at night) it really depends on the situation. A backpack would really be useful in such situations. (Note: there is a backpack in game, but it is only used for crafting mats and such, not for equpable items)

All in all, this game is really worth your time and money.

14468555.review:
Short version: The game is great if you like randomness and challenge and don't mind using keyboard input. This game is not so great if you don't have a full keyboard and numpad.

First, let me say that I absolutely LOVE SanctuaryRPG, and it's Black release is just wonderful. The project started out free (as in beer) and has since moved to a paid (Black) version.

The actual navigation of the game is basically non-existent. You have locations that you can choose to enter, but there is no "map" to speak of. The combat is interesting enough, but the real fun is in all of the randomness and volume of options. Everything is a die-roll in the background. Enter a location, die-roll determines the event / baddie. Kill a baddie, die-roll determines the loot. Perform crafting, die-roll determines the actual item. And on, and on, and on.

And all along the way, you're presented with options that change your experience. Agree with this pamphlet you just found? Your alignment just changed slightly. Solved this puzzle? Here's a sidequest that might kills you. Killed a boss? Here's a subtle customization option. I've been playing SRPG for about 3 months now (free then Black), and I've only used one class. There's a HUGE amount of gameplay variation available.

The graphics are actually very well thought out, and there is tongue-in-cheek commentary to be found in the ASCII art. You won't get a chill from seeing moonlight glinting off the water as the breeze blows through shoots of grass, but the graphical approach works well to pull off a consistent aesthetic and feel.

Now here's the caveat: you really should play with a full keyboard plus numpad. The experience is clearly tailored for a left hand on A-S-D-F and a right hand on the numpad. With this setup, the game plays smooth and the design works. If you play with a laptop, though, the fun diminishes somewhat, and if you try a touchscreen keyboard, the fun disappears.

14463938.review:

Let me say first that and I really hate ASCII, I can never get into games like Dwarf Fortress because of it, but it works really well in this game, it doesn't even faze me at this point, and it's not at all as complicated as it may seem from the screenshots, so if this sounds like something you might be concerned about, forget it because it's non issue. Oh and the music rocks!!!!!!!!! Like seriously it's so good, it's the first Soundtrack I've ever bought on Steam because it's just that good and wanted to throw more money at it.

To summarize a few things, the writing is good and leans towards being funny, not serious, the gameplay works great here, it's very unique and fits perfectly for those "play for 10 minutes and quit games" (but you won't just play 10 minutes :)).

It's also backed by some serious cool dudes, the developer just rock with how open they are with community involvement.

14459707.review:
Strangely enough, the closest comparison to SanctuaryRPG in my mind are Disgaea games despite the fact that they look and play completely differently. The reason is that both of them have made traditionally maligned grinding experience in the center of attention, and created a good game out of basically making numbers go up while going through thousands of battles.

It helps that the battles themselves strike a good balance between mindlessly repeating one winning strategy and making the player spend hours on each battle. The battle system is flexible but simple enough to get you in the sort of relaxing concentration state. Sometimes it's not very far removed from slot machines, but here you won't waste your inheritance away.

There are some things that are bothering me (things require too many keystrokes, there are some one-hit KOs remaining, the beginning gets boring after a while, some components of the game seem underutilized and some overutilized) but they're mostly minor and/or personal preference. I've enjoyed the game even if not every untimely death of my character.

14459306.review: Sanctuary is a loot-fiend's wet dream. Weapons, shields, trinkets and more, just about every fight you get that odd looking loot emblem and then the suspense. Will it be an upgrade or just another item to salvage into crafting components? Visiting the town and crafting, pouring ale for your tavern customers, reading something from the library for an XP boost. There are a lot of things to do in this text-based adventure. I haven't beaten the game yet but I keep coming back to it. There are several starting characters and races with the ability to unlock even more. The combat commands are simple (just press a number or a letter) but the complexity of it still baffles me after hours of play. Every few levels they add another layer to the combat with another option. Bottom line - For the price you get a lot of game.

14398390.review:
I was unsure about this game. I've never really played any ascii type games, except when I was too young to remember them, but I thought I'd give this one a go based on all the positive things people have said about this game, and I am 100% glad that I did!

First of all, there is so much to do, so many little quests, bounties and even the management of the tavern if you play your cards right. All of the random encounters, hilarious and often nonsensical slices of humour thrown in here and there really make this game feel so much fun. You'll find dialogue such as "A potato has decided to follow you around." to something terrifying funny like "The worm defecates in your ear." 

The ascii art work is very polished and looks as though it has had a lot of love put into it. It's charming and simple.

The gameplay, from character creation to the immense replayability and even the combat system, reminds me of one of my favourite games of all time: Tales of Maj Eyal, it has that similar feel of even if you lose, you just want to start over and try again immediately, which is an essential element to the rogue-like genre. Starting over in this game doesn't feel like a chore, because it's different each time and every character you play. There is so much loot which really is part of the glue that holds everything together, making every run through a unique and challenging experience.

The combat system is very intuitive and unique. There are a whole bunch of different skills and combos which makes the combat a real edge of your seat sort of affair, but if you play your cards right, and you take your time and are meticulous with your decisions, it will leave you feeling incredibly satisfied after a challenging fight.

Overall, I have yet to discover anything negative about this game, I love every feature and every bit of text is a delight to read. For an ascii game, it is more engaging than a lot of the games in my library, I recommend it 100%!

Also, do not be fooled by the early access sticker, because this game is very polished and clearly a very loved project by the incredibly talented developers. My hat's off to you guys!

A true throwback to the era of text-based roguelike games, this title should satiate any need you have for text-based dungeon crawling and monster murder.

*** I used a stemkey provided by the developer for review purpose ***

Gameplay: 7/10
You start off creating your character from a base class, begin ASCII customization of your appearance and information, watch the intro and you're off to scour the murky depths of a textual fantasy world. Why'd you milk that ghost? Why are you completely naked?! If you've ever played a text-based roguelike you'll be familiar with how the game executes and if not, be prepared for an immensely thorough and funny gaming experience.

Graphics: 6/10
You wouldn't think graphics in a text-based game could be much but... The ASCII art in this game is incredible for what it's medium is. Even the animation is awesome. The ability to accurately convey the art of the genre and actually be enthralling and interesting is amazing. 

Sound: 10/10
Easily my favorite part about this game is the chiptune soundtrack. The music is plentiful and mixed. The sound effects are perfectly adapted and timed. There are so many rich and warm tunes it immerses you right into the game like you wouldn't believe. I hope they release the soundtrack for this game on Steam too.

Overall: 7/10
It might not be everyones cup of tea but to anyone that loves text adventures this is a must-have. If you can type, you can enjoy this game.

14320082.review:
Probably not the best review, this would be my first game of this kind, text based/ascii art game. But for what it is, I think it does well. The ASCII art is actually rather endearing and as you put more time into it, you'll begin to look forward to getting a certain item popup, or dreading meeting a really powerful enemy as your character's life is on the line every time.

The music matches the style, "retro" but in all the best ways. There were very few songs I disliked.
The humor can be hit or miss but there's a lot of little references to popular media that I think many will appreciate.

Combat while it has a simple interface, can become rather interesting as you level. You MUST pay attention to on screen cues or you will get punished in the worst way. It isn't a game that you can just idle the same buttons, at least until you are sufficiently strong.

The first area won't be that exciting, but if you make it to the second area, you'll meet a lot more npcs which will also help you level, unlock more powerful abilities, and so on. It can actually become a bit too much if you try and manage your time between adventuring, going on npc fetch quests, messing around in the colosseum, making armor, serving drinks, etc.

Warning though, if you are a "fair player", stay away from using auto combat. Certain combinations of negative statuses on your character can confuse your CPU self making it make bad decisions (continously trying to heal or reposition when it cannot instead of breaking free from a snare) which leads to your character's demise. This may be adjusted in the future as this is an early access game, but at time of writing, this warning is accurate.

I ended up playing the game outright, so I never played the demo, but I figure it is still a good representation of the game. If you are on the fence, give it a go.

A woman approaches you and warns you of graphic scenes of digging and nsfw potatoes.
You stab yourself in the neck.

[+] Funny first couple playthroughs
[+] Inventory is convenient
[+] Battle system is very fun
[+] Music
[+] Crafting is fun
[+] Doesn't require quick reflexes, great way to chill out

[-] Steep learning curve; read below
[-] Doesn't really offer different play styles - no talent/spec builds, just stat packing
[-] Permadeath means the beginning becomes repetetive
[-] Grinding (also because of the permadeath)

Why would I recommend this game: Even though it is very simple in its gameplay, the fun random elements make it exciting and the battle system makes it very challenging. I keep finding myself coming back to it simply to chill out and enjoy playing a game that doesn't require fast reactions.

It takes time to get used to, so I recommend first downloading their "demo" (basically full game, but lacking in the black edition features) from their website. If you enjoyed it, get this game. I bought it, because I really liked the demo and thought "eh, only 4 quid, may as well suport the developers for this awesome game". I was really surprised just by how much bonus content there is in the Black Edition - I highly recommend purchasing it!

The only thing that pushed me away (initially) was the combat - I had no idea how it worked, so in case anyone reading this is wondering the same: Basically the numbers are your skills and they CHANGE if you use them, and the aim is to go from starter to linker to finish without dying (this is really simplified, but should allow you to at least navigate the combat menu).

Get the demo. If you are creating a second character and enjoying it, get the black edition.

Finally, after 18 hours and 3 characters, I've finally defeated the Matron using my level 90 Barbarian in Classic mode. I must say, it truly is satisfying!

This game... Wow, how can I put it into words. Honestly, when I first received this game, I was a bit unsure of what to expect. i didn't even know what ASCII means (guess I'm not old enough to be acquainted with the genre). For a guy with over 500 games in his library, I keep coming back to this one every now and then.

SanctuaryRPG is simply put a text-based roguelike loot-centric driven RPG. Featuring harsh permadeaths and surprisingly amount of depth in equipments, abilities and characters, this game is definitely a hidden gem to come out recently! The gameplay mostly requires you to read, enter commands, such as 1, 2, 3, A, S, and read some more. Don't be discourage though, because the developers and writers are definitely a funny bunch! Also, they seem to have an insanely amount of love to potatoes (they should probably get some help about it). Aside from the main story line, there's also dungeon exploration, matchmaking (not really online but with ranks and it decreases over time), fun little tavern management, crafting (never leave home without it!) and a Lunatic mode for those looking for a bigger challenge!

If you're still worried about the game's playtime duration, don't. Why? Aside from the numerous characters and backgrounds you can choose, the level cap is set (currently) at 300 and the trials (achievments) are insane, requiring to get the highest rank in Matchmaking, encountering 500 random events in the map, etc. Also, it's worth noting that the devs are actively updating the game, adding and fixing in the average once per week. The devs are also very friendly! You can approach them for any enquiries if you want. That's pretty rare these days, no?

I'll probably update this review in the future in case a significant update comes up and I need to put this out. It's been a blast for me to play this and I hope to continue enjoying this masterpiece of an indie game.


Personally, I give SanctuaryRPG a solid 9 / 10! Also, I'll probably never trust a hobo again after this.

14109769.review:
[i]Avis donné pendant l'accès anticipé ; Mis à jour le 8 juin 2015[/i]
------------------------------------------------------------------
SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition est un jeu (très) old-school, mélangeant éléments RPG et Rogue-like, graphismes ASCII, et combat tactique au tour par tour. N'ayant pas joué à ce genre de jeux dans mon enfance, je pensais que j'aurais vraiment du mal à aimer ce jeu. Et pourtant, après avoir joué à la démo (SanctuaryRPG: Classic, disponible sur cette page), j'ai adoré ! SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition reprend le jeu Classic, mais avec des graphismes améliorés (et oui, c'est possible même en ASCII, des aspects retravaillés, et beaucoup plus de contenu. Malgré son aspect simpliste, le jeu est tactique, et les mécanismes de jeu sont bien pensés. Deux modes de jeu sont disponibles au départ : Classic, avec permadeath pour une expérience Rogue-like ; et Softcore, pour une aventure plus détendue, avec une pénalité en cas de mort mais pas la perte de votre personnage.

[u]Les points positifs vs. points négatifs du jeu :[/u]
+ Humour omniprésent, sans être lourd
+ Mécanismes de jeu intuitifs
+ Une certaine simplicité qui ne rend pas le jeu facile ou inintéressant pour autant
+ Bonne OST, et qui colle bien avec le jeu
+ Système de combat au tour par tour simple mais réellement tactique
+ Elements RPG réussis
+ Exploration agréable, motivée par la recherche de loot, les évènements aléatoires, et la soif de découvertes
+ Côté old-school réussi
+ Beaucoup de contenu, un grand nombre de classes, divers armes et autres équipements
+ Un jeu original, ça change !
+ Jeu addictif !
+/- Graphismes ASCII qui ne plairont peut-être pas à tout le monde (mais auxquels on s'habitue, et qui font vraiment le charme du jeu)
+/- Les influences Rogue-like risquent de ne pas plaire à ceux qui veulent la facilité
+/- Jeu exclusivement en Anglais (je suppose que c'est un moins pour certains)

SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition est un très bon jeu, simple mais addictif, original, et dans lequel simplicité ne veut pas dire facilité. Le prix peut paraitre un peu élevé, mais lorsqu'on a essayé le jeu (même la démo), on comprend que jeu vaut bien 5€ ! Donc, si vous hésitez, je vous conseille de télécharger la démo. C'est un jeu complet, une sorte de version antérieure de SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition, qui est moins soigné, dispose de beaucoup moins de contenu, mais qui vous permettra de voir si ce jeu est fait pour vous ou non. En tout cas, je recommande !

14063817.review:
SanctuaryRPG to gra zachowana w stylistyce z początków istnienia gatunku. Jako taka okazuje się zaskakująco przyjemna w rozgrywce. Polecam serdecznie i sądzę, że nikt kto sięgnie po tą pozycję się nie zawiedzie. (Chyba :F)

Fabuła:
Fabuła jako taka sięga do sprawdzonych rozwiązań, lecz czyni to z odpowiednią dawką humoru sprawiając jednocześnie, iż czytanie kolejnych dialogów ma miejsce, a gracz nie ogranicza się jedynie do bezmyślnego klikania przycisku enter co by szybciej nadmiary tekstu przewinąć. Grę przeszedłem dopiero raz więc nie dam głowy czy w "grze plus" nie ma nowych rozwiązań fabularnych, ale ów jeden raz był przyjemną przygodą.

Rozgrywka:
Jak to na ten typ gry przystało by wpływać na świat gry posługujemy się wpisywaniem odpowiedniego tekstu w miejsce wyznaczone, a później zatwierdzamy daną wiadomość enterem. Choć brzmi to nieco strasznie to twórcy SanctuaryRPG podeszli do tego tematu bardzo współcześnie ułatwiając to niecodzienne zadanie za pomocą z góry ustalonych opcji do wyboru opisanych odpowiednim numerem lub literą. Tak więc chcąc szukać wyzwania wpiszemy 1,2 lub trzy (zależnie od dostępnych dostępnych w danym czasie opcji) lub chcąc odwiedzić kowala wybierzemy literkę Q. Wszystkie możliwości są wyświetlane na ekranie więc nie trzeba się tego uczyć na pamięć :)
Przystosowanie się do mechaniki walki może zająć drobną chwilę, ale jest to zajęcie wbrew pozorom dość intuicyjne. Klasycznie staramy się wyprowadzić jak najdłuższe kombinację ciosów, a w chwilach konieczności leczymy otrzymane obrażenia (resetując przy okazji licznik combo!). Co pewien czas można także wykonać ciosy specjalne bądź też wykorzystać wydarzenia losowe podczas walki (np. okazja do przewrócenia przeciwnika albo wykonanie śmiałej szarży). Przypadkowe eventy mają także miejsce podczas naszych wędrówek. Warto więc przygotować się do wytężenia uwagi i wypatrywania okazji do ich użycia jako, że są one aktywowane odpowiednim przyciskiem pokazywanym na ekranie (np. możliwość zbadania przypadkowych jaskini, obrabowanie żebraka, śpiewanie do magicznych kryształów i temu podobne).
Śmierć jako taka jest tutaj definitywnym końcem chyba, że wybierzemy bardziej przyjazną opcję dla casualowych graczy. Pomiędzy postaciami można przenosić z pomocą okolicznej tawerny srebrne klucze oraz rodzaj pewnego 

Grafika: 
Um... To ASCII. Love it or hate it. 
A co by nie ulegać wszechobecnym makaronizmom angielskim myśl tę rozwinę. Ten rodzaj grafiki w spektakularny sposób ukazuję jak wiele można osiągnąć za pomocą gry wyobraźni. Z rzeczy bardziej zaskakujących czcionka potrafi przybierać różnorakie kolory, jednakże nie jest to rozwiązanie nadużywane w złym guście i smaku. Reasumując pozorna ubogość formy pozwala na większe skupienie na bezpośredniej rozgrywce.

Muzyka:
Jeden z mocniejszych punktów produkcji. Z początku zdarzało się, że w jakichś miejscach dźwięk nikł lub nie występował wcale, ale kilka łatek później mogę ze spokojnym sumieniem polecić ten aspekt gry. Dobrze dopasowane brzmienie podkreślające dynamikę rozgrywających się wydarzeń. Pełna napięcia muzyka podczas walk, osobne melodię na starcia z bossami oraz specjalne kawałki w chwilach odnalezienia magicznych artefaktów. Wszystko to co tygryski lubią najbardziej.

Podsumowanie.
Jeżeli nie boisz się krzaczastej grafiki to jest to gra dla Ciebie. Jeżeli chcesz rozwikłać zagadkę mitycznej Matrony i latających ziemniaków to jest to gra dla Ciebie. Jednakże siląc się na obiektywizm dodam także może jakie mam uwagi do gry. Hm... Jedynym minusem nasuwającym się na myśl jest wbrew pozorom dość wyśrubowany poziom trudności areny, ale i powtarzalność walk, które się na niej rozgrywają. Sporo wysiłku by zdobyć (niedostępny jeszcze w czasie pisania recenzji) achievement na steamie. Ale ogólnie polecam serdecznie :D

13978290.review:
This is pretty much the best not-BBS-door-but-totally-a-BBS-door RPG I have ever played. 

+Very unique and fast paced turn based combat that involves strategically countering moves and repositioning yourself for maximum damage.
+Tons of races, stats, mixing/matching and a bunch of other character customization options I don't care about but other people will LOVE
+A CAMPAIGN. Seriously, split into acts and everything. This thing is meaty.
+Awesome, chip tuney music. And LOTS of variety it so it doesn't get annoying. 
+The graphics are pretty great. Good scenes and enemy portraits. CHARM.
+Great interface that you can navigate ultra fast, just like the old days of BBSing and MUDding
+Option to play casually without permadeath (with caveats, but the option is there)
+Ridiculous and well written dialog and characters
+So much loot and a great equipping/salvaging system that means zero inventory management.
+Murder a bartender and take over her tavern
+Burn religious tracts
+Mine, gather, salvage and craft your own armor, charms and weapons
+Player housing


-Can't play it on my phone
-Can't skip some of the beginning area stuff when you die or reroll
-Would prefer an ultra casual option with no caveats so I don't have to save scum

Don't be fooled by the ASCII graphics on this one. It may look and feel old school but there are plenty of modern RPG conventions that make this game a pleasure to play. If it piques your interest, just buy the stupid thing. It's good. REAL GOOD.

13960503.review:
I love ASCII graphics. I love rouge-likes. AND AT FIRST

I WAS HORRIFIED at what i was seeing and doing in this game. The charm immediatly appealed to me,  but the game play itself seemed incredibly lack-luster. To the point of "what am i even doing here?"


That was until I leveled up a few times, and had about thirty or so encounters and suddenly, i was finding myself entertained. Im not sure when it happend. probably as i learned what all the combat indicators where atually telling me to do, and now im afraid this game has achieved candy crush level of addictiveness for me. And it all has to do with the rouge like nature of the item drops and encounters. Watching the little animation play as you know its generating up a item is fun, and feels like gambling in a bizzare way. 

This is a game that opens so incredibly narrow in its presentation i almost rage quited to uninstall- having assumed i made a terrible mistake. But thank god i didnt, or i would be missing out. 

Fighting,Mining, crafting, tavern running- its all as interactive as a few button presses. But my god! do the button presses feel good! (Once you know how mighty striking that 4 key truely is)

The music? spot on. Ive left the game minimized just to enjoy it while i did some other things not involving pressing numericals. 

The battles? Once you know what you are doing, are fun and can be extremely challenging

Leveling is intuitive and not too bogged down with fluff (INT, STR, DEX ect. do as you would assume) 

talking to freindly NPC's are only worth the quirky lines and the occasional reward for even bothering. otherwise, interactions could use some work (looping dialogs) 

Pacing is difficult, as you would expect from a rouge like. 

~I KNOW I HAVE NOT SEEN ALL THIS TITLE HAS TO OFFER~ i just feel it. 

SO, to summarize, this is a wonderful little peice of classic gaming. Not for everyone, but certainly for me. If  reading (gasp) and dying permanently is not fun for you- dont bother with this. 
but as we know, LOSING IS FUN! and READING IS ..FUN! 

Also.. the level of "oh, thank god i did that other wise id have missed (insert thing here)" is just right. Talk to people, wander around. Its worth it!

13914024.review:
Uzun zamandır bu tarz bir oyun bekliyorum desem yalan söylemiş olmam. Yazı (ASCII) tabanlı RYO oyunların özlemini hepimiz çekmişizdir. SanctuaryRPG bu hasretimize son veriyor. Sizi uzun süre kendine bağlayacak ve başından kalkamayacaksınız. Yazı tabanlı “roguelike” RYO’ya olan özleminizi, hasretinizi kesinlikle gidereceksiniz.

SanctuaryRPG roguelike tarzını bize yeniden yaşatacak bir yapım. Yazı tabanlı rol yapma oyunlarının en güzel yanı her şeyin sizin hayal dünyanıza kalmış olması. Son zamanlarda çıkan grafiğe yüklenilmiş senaryodan ve oynanıştan yoksun AAA yapımları oynamaktansa SanctuaryRPG gibi yapımların başında saatler geçirebilirim.

Geniş bir evrene, hikâyeye sahip olan oyun bir o kadar da geniş olanaklar sunuyor bizlere. Roguelike bir RYO oyununda aradığımız ne varsa SanctuaryRPG’de bulabiliyoruz. Eksiği yok fazlası var denecek türden. Oyun erken erişime açıldığı günden bu güne Steam üzerinde henüz hiçbir olumsuz yorum almamış durumda. Erken erişim oyunlarda genellikle karşılaşılan sorunlardan ve yetersiz içerikten dolayı birçok oyunun oldukça fazla olumsuz yorum ve oylama aldığını görmüşüzdür. SanctuaryRPG’de ise durum tam tersi. Toplam 163 Olumlu ve “Sıfır” olumsuz yoruma sahip bir yapım şu an itibariyle.

Roguelike ve JapaneseRPG türüyle harmanlanmış olan içeriğinin yanı sıra Action-RPG savaş türüyle oynanmakta olan bir oyun. Karşılaşmalar turn-based (sıra tabanlı) olarak gerçekleşmekte. Bunların yanı sıra SanctuaryRPG yazı tabanlı bir oyun olmasında rağmen bir sinematiği de mevcut ve oldukça başarılı. Oyunun oynanışı tamamen komut gönderme sistemine bağlı olarak çalışmakta. Mouse kullanmıyoruz ve eski yazı tabanlı DOS oyunlarında olduğu gibi komut yazarak işlem yapıyoruz.

Peki yazı tabanlı bir oyunda kendi karakterimizi yaratırken ne gibi özellikler ekleyebiliyoruz, sadece adımız mı? – Hayır!

... incelemenin tamamı için: http://8piksel.com/sanctuaryrpg-black-edition/inceleme/

SanctuaryRPG için 8piksel puanı: 9.8/10

13908692.review:
グラフィックがAA(アスキーアート)で表現されたコマンド選択式のRPG。
コマンド選択式といっても今風のRPGの要素は大体含まれているので、テキストベースならではの想像力を掻き立てられるRPGという印象。
キャラメイクやハクスラ要素をはじめ、基本固定ストーリーだがサイドクエストやランダム性の高いイベントなどもありローグライクと言えなくもない。
ハイリスクハイリターンでギャンブル性の高いクラフトシステムも面白い。
レアリティの高いアイテムがドロップすると特別な音楽が流れたりするあたりはテンションが上がる。
そのほか、レベルアップ時のスキル選択・ステータス強化、アイテム強化・採掘、傭兵システムなど、取り入れられるだけの要素を盛り込んだゲームシステムとなっている。
くせがあるゲームのため、購入前にデモをおすすめする。
個人的に気に入っているのが音楽で、1曲1曲のクオリティが高く、
なおかつ曲数が50曲以上あり、インディーズゲームとしては珍しいバリエーションの高さだと思う。

13901525.review:
Lo jugué en su modo normal y no tardé mucho en comprarlo luego aquí en Steam una vez que salió.
De momento está todavía en acceso anticipado lo que quiere decir que puede que algunas cosas cambien pero escribo mi análisis a pesar de ello, y tal vez luego haya cosas que cambie.

El que haya jugado ambas versiones verá que mientras que la historia, el número de actos y algunas características más son las mismas, hay otras que se han añadido, modificado o eliminado. Con eliminado me refiero a que en la normal el guardián tenía tres modos y uno de ellos te daban un +20% más de vida con los turnos que iban pasando, algo que cambia en la Black Edition; lo cual es comprensible porque de tener mil de vida uno terminaba teniendo tres millones y hacía el juego más fácil. En la Black Edition se han añadido más cosas, ya sea más habilidades por parte de los enemigos como zonas a donde ir beneficiosas para nuestro personaje. Dichas zonas serían la biblioteca o el templo, otras se mantienen como el herrero o la taberna.
Otros añadidos son nuevos orígenes (muchos de ellos desbloqueables al progresar en la historia), nuevas habilidades por obtener y objetos muuuuuy extraños de conseguir para el personaje. También se ha agregado la posibilidad de elegir un bando u otro, hermandad o resistencia, o simplemente ser neutral; algo que irá cambiando conforme vayas encontrándose panfletos por ahí y elijas una opción u otra.
Por hablar de más diferencias se podría añadir que algunas «imágenes» de algunos enemigos han sido cambiadas y se han añadido más dibujos para lo que antes no había más que texto. Por ejemplo vemos el acto 4, donde en la edición normal lo pasé dos veces y es el acto que menos me gustó porque se me hizo pesado, en cambio en la Black Edition eso no me ha ocurrido. Se ha añadido más texto, el que haya día y noche (antes no había) hace la diferencia para mí ya que prefiero usar la noche para ir a la biblioteca a leer y demás. Es decir, el acto 4 se me ha hecho más ameno en esta edición entre una cosa y otra.
Más o menos diría que son las desemejanzas que he ido viendo, para los que no hayáis jugado a la anterior es mejor que saltéis hasta aquí:

El juego es todo texto y meter teclas para hacer una acción u otra, no hay gráficos per se, lo que hay son dibujos en ASCII. Para atacar basta con usar teclas como 1, 2, 3, Q, R y un par más. Para curarse uno hace el uso del 4. El juego es por turnos y en esencia es bastante sencillo lo que viene ser el atacar o desplazarse.
Hay varios personajes, está el asesino (yo personalmente uso este), el arquero, el bárbaro, el paladín, el mago y el druida. Todos ellos personalizables, puedes elegir su origen para recibir beneficios además de su género, complexión (el cual también da un beneficio u otro) y unos cuantos diseños para la cara y pelo. No vas a verle mucho la cara a tu personaje, así que en realidad da igual. Cada personaje dependiendo de su clase será favorecido de una forma u otra (al asesino no le conviene usar armadura pesada, por ejemplo, pero sí se beneficia bien de la destreza), pero como en cualquier juego, los comandos para cada ataque son los mismos, las teclas 1, 2 y 3 las vas a tocar en cualquier personaje.
El nivel máximo es 300, así que hay para rato, y más si uno juega en modo clásico de lo cual hablaré ahora:

El juego tiene modo clásico y softcore. El clásico es el «típico», de ahí que el juego sea un rogue-like, si tu personaje muere, despídete de él y empieza de nuevo. Quien haya jugado a Akalabeth, Realm of the Mad God o incluso a los libros juego de Lobo Solitario sabrá de qué va el tema.
En cambio en softcore uno puede morir, tiene sus desventajas como tener menos posibilidad de drops pero es más seguro. Al morir la única penalización que se tiene es perder la experiencia obtenida en ese nivel y todo el dinero.

En cuanto a la historia del juego... consta de cinco actos, cada uno de ellos con varias zonas por las que avanzar y con enemigos por derrotar. De vez en cuando se puede encontrar a personajes que solamente soltarán alguna frase o puede que regalen algo, otras veces se ven panfletos, también te puedes topar con eventos en los que puedes conseguir armaduras o armas; y también hay veces que se pueden explorar zonas extra si se da la opción.
Volviendo a la historia me recordó un poco a la saga de libros de Los proscritos y los desterrados, me daba la sensación de estar viviendo esos libros. En principio puede ser un poco confuso, ¿quiénes son los «buenos»? ¿quiénes son los «malos»? Depende de cada uno la elección mientras vaya avanzando. Poco a poco también sabremos más sobre la gente que nos acompaña. Pero no queda ahí, el juego cuenta con referencias y bromas (como el que se da en los orígenes de cada personaje), lo cual depende de cada uno que las capte o no y su humor.
El juego es lineal en cuanto a historia, sí, pero los eventos que suceden en el juego son aleatorios.

Ya hablé de «zonas beneficiosas para nosotros», ¿verdad? Esos sitios son el herrero y más. 
Básicamente es lo mismo que en cualquier juego: el herrero es para conseguir armas, la mercader para conseguir otros objetos, la biblioteca para leer y ganar más experiencia, el coliseo para pelear contra enemigos y subir de rango y nivel, etcétera.
El juego dispone de un sistema de crafteo, donde uno puede crear sus propias armaduras, armas y escudos, y no está dejado al azar, uno tiene que ir viendo si le conviene usar una acción u otra aunque pueda llegar a romper el objeto que se está creando en cuestión, o bien ir demasiado tranquilo y ser de muy baja calidad.

Por último queda hablar del idioma, la dificultad, la ost y su duración:
El juego está en inglés, solamente es texto así que no hay voces; pero es en inglés al menos de momento. Se puede jugar perfectamente sin conocer el idioma pero lógicamente se pierde la historia de juego.
¿La OST? A mí me gusta y el ambiente que da también, encaja con el juego y no es de las que se hacen pesadas. A quien le guste mucho mucho siempre puede comprarla.
Y la duración, bueno, depende. En la versión normal tengo cerca de treinta horas y me lo pasé dos veces en softcore. En la Black Edition cuento con catorce horas en el momento en el que estoy escribiendo este análisis, pero mi partida en el modo clásico es de unas 7-8 horas con mi segundo asesino (el primero murió al llevar 1-2h de juego). El resto son unas cuantas en softcore y algún personaje salteado para probar en clásico. Con lo que el juego en sí si se quiere pasar una vez y en softcore se hace rápido, pero si es en el modo clásico se puede tardar más si no se conocen las mecánicas. Y más si se quiere llegar al nivel máximo, que como dije es 300.
¿Fácil o difícil? Bueno, la mecánica del juego es fácil, llegar hasta el final en la primera partida y en el modo clásico no tanto. Los enemigos cuentan con varios estados y habilidades, unos te envenarán, te provocarán sangrado, se sanarán, te dejarán sin maná entre otras. Y si uno no es precavido, no conoce todavía cómo funciona cada cosa o incluso tiene mala suerte, pues puede morir por un mísero slime. Y claro, morir en modo clásico y más si es cerca del final, duele. Yo recomiendo que para quienes no hayan jugado al juego lo suyo es que se lo pasen al menos una vez en softcore y ya luego pasar al clásico. Gracias a que me pasé la antigua versión dos veces en softcore no he tenido problemas en el modo clásico en ésta. En mi segunda partida he podido llegar al final sin problemas, así que como dije, que sea difícil o no depende de lo familiarizado que esté uno y el modo de juego.

¿Que si recomiendo este juego? Si te gustan los juegos por turnos, no te importa tener que empezar de nuevo si mueres y no te molesta el hecho de que sea en texto, al contrario, te llama la atención, sí, deberías probarlo.

13900511.review:
[h1] Graphics: [/h1] 10/10. The game is completely made up of ASCII, and the art people did a brilliant job. Don't expect Bloom with 4XMSAA, and don't worry if you don't own four GTX 980s.
[h1] Soundtrack: [/h1] 9/10. It makes the game feel more immersive and complete. Makes you feel calm on the title screen, gets you pumped up when fighting a miniboss. The soundtrack, along with the art, is what make the game different.
[h1] Writing: [/h1] 100/10. BEST HUMOUR EVAR
[h1] User Interface: [/h1] 8/10. Press [1] to perform an action, press [2] to perform another action. How simpler can it get?
[h1] Learning Curve: [/h1] 7/10. I couldn't understand most of the stuff that was going on around my screen in the first playthrough. I guess it's just me, but I found the game pretty difficult.
[h1] Overall: [/h1] 9/10. It's "Critically Acclaimed" for a reason.

(I'm no critic, so the numbers aren't critical.)

13889945.review:
Alright, I'm going to start by saying my time played is not exactly reflective of the days of my life this game has taken, I just happen to have a save in classic I'm trying to finish/eventually die horribly in running alongside playing black edition. That said, there's really not much to hate about this game, it's a solid roguelike, a great comedy rpg, and the ascii art is of as high a quality as you'll probably ever find, about the only complaint I can really make is that the random selection for individual avatar parts has a knack of choosing the same feature 2-4 times in a row

If you're into roguelikes, get this game. If you're into rpgs, get this game, try it in classic mode, then if you can't stand the inevitable loss of your character, try again in softcore, but unless you have no sense of humor, a hatred of words, or view casual gaming as the pinnacle of good games, there's no reason not to at least give this game a try

Oh yeah, and did I mention you can have your paladin be an atheist? Because you totally can.

In conclusion, the most important thing for any roguelike is to be fun enough that when you do die, you feel inspired to try again, rather than to give up because sir bob refused to run fast enough to outrun an angry boss and now all your super special, carefully crafted loot is lost, and this game has managed that perfectly, 10/10

13884580.review:
100% из 165 обзоров этой игры положительны.
Нечасто такое увидишь, хоть и понятно, что это до первой распродажи, которая привлечёт изрядное количество случайных людей, разъярённых ASCII-графикой.
Сейчас же, пока тут ещё все свои, ничего удивительного в таком успехе нет. Даже теперь, когда игра находится в "раннем доступе", придраться решительно не к чему, а ежедневные обновления делают её только лучше.
Ностальгии по графике такого рода у меня нет, в детстве я играл в игры, где графика, хотя и простая, но всё же была, как минимум, на уровне EGA, а игры вроде Hunt the Wumpus или Star Trek (это который текстовый), уже и на тот момент древние, меня надолго не увлекали. Тем не менее, графика здесь великолепна. Каждый символ - на своём месте, притом ничего лишнего. Как нет ничего лишнего и в геймплее. Всё достаточно просто, интуитивно и снабжено контекстной информацией, в отличие от многих классических RPG, прежде чем засесть за которые, было надобно сперва прочесть многостраничное руководство. При этом водить за руку, как во многих нынешних играх, никто не будет. Неправильное развитие героя может закончиться для него трагически, особенно в "классическом" режиме, где герой, померев, исчезает навсегда. Возможностей же для развития имеется немало, как и разнообразного случайного барахла. 
Можно строить избушку, рыть шахту, крафтить имущество.
Можно торговать пивом и кривляться на потеху публике в таверне, отжатой (нагло или вежливо) у владелицы.
Можно нанять в помощь банду разгильдяев.
Можно участвовать в восстании; можно не участвовать.
Можно расправиться с врачом-вредителем.
Можно в храме божьем приносить в жертву живую картошку.
Забавно, что  можно даже менять внешность персонажа - и это в ASCII-графике!
Грабить корованы, кажется, нельзя. :(
Вообще, атмосфера игры неповторима, как и чувство приключения.
Саундтрек хорош настолько, что я слушаю его и отдельно от игры.
Не хватает только версии для Linux, которая, впрочем, обещана.
И вот - сто шестьдесят шестой положительный обзор.

Update: Версии для Линукса не будет. >_<

13876806.review:
Okay so for those too lazy too read the information on the product and as a cheap way to write an introduction, SanctuaryRPG is an ASCII Rpg, meaning it is a text based Rpg with the addition of ASCII artworks. 

And it actually does a pretty good job at utilizing it, for example by creating backgrounds via ASCII there are some "hidden" paths, meaning there is either an "x" marking an entrance to a cave, house or something else, or treasure chests which are marked with a "7" if there is one or "77"/"88"/"99" if there is three, interaction is done by hitting the corresponding keys.

The fights are based on the usage of 8 different moves out of which 3 are unlocked by leveling up and one by advancing the story (first 5 minutes top), for more information check http://sanctuaryrpg.wikia.com/wiki/Battle_Hub

Simply put it is a simplistic system and the most challenging thing is to not start fighting using a pattern without paying attention to what is going on, beacuse that is always the times when you will die, if you pay attention all the time it is pretty much impossible to die once you get the hang of enemies abilities and behaviour.

The game is focused on a simple objective defeat a bad guy, do that by going places, go to places by killing bosses, by killing minions, monsters and animals prior to that. In addition to that you have a crafting system which consist of hitting materials in one of 3 manners, waiting or by crafman skill level based abilities, in order to get the highest numbers, pretty much like any other Rpg. You also have some NPCs to interact with, doing quests, talking, buying or selling stuff, once more the usual things for a Rpg. You spend your time on teh fields for the formerly killing of various entinities, your camp (for crafting), the tavern earning money and questing, the arena killing people and random dungeons, or even the library (mainly you just get bored or get dizzy from the reading) other thatn that a temple. What you can do at the different places should be obvious, one important thing to mention in addition to the, currently, four difiiculty levels to pick from when starting the game, you can adjust the strength of enemies at the temple, in the version at the time of the review, it could change, as it used to be the arena back in the itch.io days.  

Based on the "review" up to now you might wonder "Well if it is just a simplistic game, which is kinda artsy by using a graphics style from over 20 years ago, why would I buy it?" and, lucky you, there actually is a reason: the humour (though you might want to take that with a pinch of salt, after all us germans are known for not having a good sense for it).
Still from my point of view it is quite good, even though it does include a fair share of overused jokes, toilet humour and puns, it still manages to entertain me with it.

I also should add that I spend most of my time with the game prior to its release on steam, when it was only out on itch.io, so I can't tell you a whole lot about the additions of the black edition, I can still tell you about my experience with how fast game crashing or breakings bugs are dealt with, as the game is currently still in early access.
During the 7 hours of playing the steam version 1.00 to 1.04 I encountered one game crash which included save corruption (immoratilty, instakilling every opponent, item drops crashing the game) and while that is the only bug and crash I ever encountered I should also mention that I also have encountered this one in the non-steam version.
In that case around 10 times in at least 50hours+, sadly I could never figure out what caused it in order to avoid it.
Otherwise bugs are pretty rare, though some patches cause new ones, the last one caused by a patch was fixed with a new patch the very next day.

Overall I can easily recommend the game in its current state for the price point of 5€.

13857490.review:
--This review was written shortly after the game's release on Steam in early access--

SanctuaryRPG puts a fresh and somewhat modern spin on the roguelike genre. The combat harkens back to turn-based JRPGs while remaining complex and engaging, as well as Dungeons and Dragons with it's strong, class-based system. There are also many things to do outside of combat, such as crafting, building up a camp, running a tavern, etc. It may seem strange to have to pay for a roguelike, but the price is low ($5 at the time of this review) and updates (both bugfixes and new content) are frequent enough to justify the expense. 

Other most other roguelikes, this game is played entirely through a series of menus, rather than as an avatar on a map. I love the concept of roguelikes but detest having to moving tile by tile through uninspiring and garbled ASCII dungeons, and SanctuaryRPG removes that from the genre.

There are two things I don't like about the game and they are the sense of humour and the quality of the story. The story is thin and generic, and the sense of humour is incredibly childish, but the game plays so well that these aspects can be ignored by those who don't enjoy them.

This game is for people that every turn base RPGs from the early nintendo era or even before that. To those people I recomend the game.

Now let me tell you about my 1st game... rather how it ended.



So I went to my tavern. There was a few dozen people there and I decided to serve them all. Half way through I drink a bunch of beers to give me some energy to enterain my patrons. I drank a ton of beer and got drunk. Serving all the remaining I closed up for the night. Then I went off in the woods and found a hidden path! What lie was a human BOSS level dude with about 10 times my HP.

That was okay. I am used to seeing really beefy enemies. I had a charm that was pretty epic: when I took damage the amount I took was reflected back to the traget. Every time. That was actually my 1st item I crafted and must have gotten super lucky! So even if I just healed myself every turn and took some damage I could basically kill anything.

Well... being drunk blocks your command section, I found out. I was doing GREAT till the boss rooted/ entangled me. I didn't notice it and took a few turns healing. But because I was trapped I could not use my heal. I didn't notice it right away because my command section was blocked off. On the last round before I died I was like Ohhhhh I think I am rooted! So I broke free. Then was killed.

I played as a ice-person race paladin and made it to level 24 in my 4 hour game. Oddly enough I am not really upset! I had such a great time that story (ie character). Yes loosing did suck but loosing can indeed be fun too!

There is a FREE version of the game that is a bit older without some of the newer features and such. So you can try it yourself and get an idea of how the game plays to see if you like it. But its only $4.99 USD right now in early access. And I must say the early access feels like a finished game now. If I had not known it was an early release I would never have guessed it.

Tons of replay value. Tons of possible random events. Tons of enemies and items. No two battles or items will be identical! But I can see how playing it for 100 hours would be repetitive for some people. Its easy to play and the combat is actually pretty complex under-the-hood. There are some actual tactics to be had in how this turn base ascii game runs! I am very pleased with this game. And in all truth when I died after the inital "Noooooo awwwww D: " passed I felt like clapping! Seriously was that fun to me!

If you are an old school gamer and have five dollars to spare then please consider supporting/ owning Santuary RPG. I give this game 8/10

13830117.review:
This game is absolutely amazing. These not much more to say. Heres my list why I love it:

Pros:
Great ASCII graphics
Bursts of great humor planted in the best places.
The abillity to murder the tavern owner, then run the tavern for yourself.
Nice loot, difficulty, and variety of places to explore and go.
A market to buy metals, a blacksmith to buy and forge weapons, your own home to craft and mine, (no joke, you mine for iron to buy armor) a tavern to buy beer, (or as I already stated, run yourself) an arena to fight and clear dungeons, among many others.
Surprisingly, very easy to approach, and not very confusing to beginners. 
Amazing old school music, making each battle welcome just for one of the epic songs.
The ability to change the difficulty of monsters in a temple, as well as join one of two religions.
Not another 'retro-pixel rpg dungeon crawler for epic lewts,' it is an actual RPG game about fighting monsters using a variety of tactics and weapons.
A good amount of loot. Not too little, and not throwing hordes of crap at your face, a variety of different types (charms, armor, shields, weapons) and a good constant chance that you'll find a better weapon.
Fresh combat, based on linking combos in turns, but with enemies throwing all kinds of things at you, forcing you to change to survive.
Constant updates

Cons:
ASCII graphics, if its not your thing
Extreme difficulty, with not much of an option to make it easier than default, other than going into an extremely cheaty feeling mode where you cant die, its only a huge setback.
Some random elements can be frustrating, such as trying to walk from point A to point B, but monsters attacking you about 10 times before you can reach point B.
Not very open world, which I think would be a really fun addition to this game.
Sometimes its humor can be annoying, for example, my character saw something shiny on the ground. My choices were something like kick it, look at it, pick it up, or walk away. I chose to pick it up. It says something around the lines of "you start to pick it up, but drop it, and it breaks forever. Oh well." I really wanted to know what that tiny thing was :(

Overall, amazing game, exactly as it is. If I didn't know this was early access, I never would. I remember this being a pay-what-you-want game from a long time ago, and it has certainly come very far from that. I may be raving about how amazing it is, and maybe I went a bit overboard with all the adjectives, but all the pros and cons I made were all true. 

9/10, only getting better

Hello,

first of all, I'm honestly not much of a reviewer but after playing this game, I simply couldn't resist to share my thoughts. I was very skeptical, yet curious what this game would be like, because I had a dream of a game that would combine the best elements from text adventures with the best elements of rpgs.

I was wondering if this is the game I always had in my mind and wanted to play and I'm very excited to say that this game simply made my dream come true and it did not stop there! It actually expanded beyond what I could ever imagine would be possible in text-adventure-rpg type of game! Seriously! For example, I've played countless of text adventures in my life, but never, I repeat never any that would let you customize the personality and even look of your character, all in ASCII graphics. I can see clearly that authors had put seriously huge effort into introducing this genre into current generation of players, great job developers!

Are you a fan of text adventures and rpg games like me or maybe more of a current-generation player, newcomer to this type of games and just little curious? Did you ever want to play a game that would combine the best from both genres and even beyond, apart from having the main game story line, adding multiple extra features, modern elements, side tasks, mining, crafting, building, shopping, talking with npc's, learning new game story related facts, learning and improving your in-game skills, fighting all kinds of monsters, magic, finding items from common things like wood planks for building, crafting to rare items, weapons, armor and other things to help you survive on your journey, exploring, looking for secret places, have fun and laugh at countless of funny moments, situations and things in game even at time and place you would never expect that? 13642086.review:
Quick note prior to the review:  If you wish to play an older, but completely free version of SanctuaryRPG, head on over to www.playsrpg.com.  It may be an older version, but it gives you plenty of content to test and is very fun.

Now, onto the review itself.

SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition is a text based RPG based off the old classic RPGs, while also taking inspiration from many new-age RPGs and JRPGs.  Seeing as I'm a fan of reviews listing information about how the game is played and the strong points of it's systems, I'll explain a bit of it, and what I like about it.

Combat:  This makes up a lot of the game, and as such, is an important system.  Combat works on a turn based system using abilities and combos.  Select one of your attacks with the corrosponding number or letter key, press enter.  Simple.  There are 6 different classes, each with their own attacks and special abilities, which gives the game great variety on how you like to combat your enemies.  In addition, all classes have their own ultimate abilities which are charged based on the use of combos.  Ultimate abilities work much like you think they would, and each one has it's own advantages.  The game also features lots of status effects and enemy affixes, which can change the pace and strategy of the fight significantly.  There's also many other different types of abilities with their own special uses you will unlock later in the game and experience for yourself.

Events:  This game features random events you may find throughout your adventure.  Events will usually occur when you find a secret area, indicated with either an [8] or a [x] on the scene depicted in the menu.  Events are usually some random choice based event.  One such event might go as follows:

(A giant cow is blocking your path.)

[1]  Jump on it.
[2]  Kiss it.
[3]  Smack it.
[4]  Walk away.

Depending on which answer you select, there may be consequences or rewards ranging from being damaged down to 1hp, healed to full health or being rewarded with a random item drop.  There's a wide variety of events, some more humorous than others, and plenty of loot to get from them.

Crafting:  Yes, there's crafting, and the system for it is pretty neat as well.  Using different crafting abilities, and there's many more to unlock by leveling up your crafting skill, you need to fill the progress bar while also watching your durability, heat, and quality in order to ensure better stats.

These are a few of the systems inside of both the classic SanctuaryRPG and the new SanctuaryRPG: Black Edition.  I've played quite a bit of the classic, but only just gotten ahold of a copy of the Black Edition (Thanks again, Devs :D) and look forward to seeing all the differences and rebalances.

Overall, I'd probably rate this game a good 82/100.  If you're one to enjoy text based RPGs at all, you'll more than likely enjoy this.

13615894.review: SanctuaryRPG is a highly accessible, text-based roguelike RPG that advances quickly and features random areas and events, loot, and crafting (the crafting system involves a forge mini-game and then an item roll), with a retro arcade video game sound track that enhances drama and ambiance.  There's plenty of humor and nods to prior classics and while the game is text-based (and super fast!) there are ASCII graphical elements that bring the game alive.  The combat system is fluid with turn-based actions that chain together to unlock damaging finishers, along with moves that will deal damage to your foe and heal yourself, saving your Heals for better uses.  My first character, in full roguelike mode (which they call Classic; a multi-life mode is available) and with luck from some good drops, has survived to Level 7 with very exciting game play -- I found the game immediately enjoyable and addicting.  Very highly recommended!

You can craft things, beat things, find secret rooms hidden in the ascii art, experience random events and pretty much do all sorts of goofy things.

The game feels like a bunch of little mini-games taped together. I'd almost describe it as D&D meet WarioWare only with ascii graphics.

If you want a fun, lightweight game to play pretty much any time then this is one for you. I might dump hundreds of hours into more 'hardcore' games but I don't think many other games would be as fun to play on a rainy day than this one.

13564863.review:
I love this game with all of my heart.  I remember playing the  game Ancient Domains Of Mystery (ADOM) as a teenager and absolutely falling in love with it.  Sancturary and ADOM are different beasts, except in their ASCII graphic style and their storytelling/dialogue that absolutely draws you in, as, well as their roguelike qualities.  But it's what they share that makes them so equally loveable.

I won't pretend to completely understand ASCII or the ASCII art and graphic style, although you can find fascinating information about both on wikipedia.  All I know is that this art style and the ability to create pictures and the like from it is truly impressive.  Between the ASCII art, the programming made to create the game, and the creativity in the game world itself this game is absolutely worth 5 dollars if not more.

  Random encounters, permadeath (only if you want it), multiple choices in every situation, random story and scenario situations ala roguelikes, mining, crafting, weapon/armor gambles, great soundtrack,  funny dialogue, engaging yet easily accesible combat, leveling, secrets, progression, etc, etc.

this game really has a lot to offer and for over 10,000 hours put into its making I feel like 5 dollars is an incredibly reasonable price.

Just for reference the lead developer gave me a steam key for this game since i obtained the earlier version in a few bundles before it was on steam.  But honestly this game is so good i plan on buying it for at least two other people before the christmas season ends.  The developers for this game are absolute gentleman and they deserve as much praise as they can get!

Please upvote this if you agree that this game is amazing and/or if you would like to show the developers your appreciation!  I really think they deserve it :).

13560419.review:
TLDR:
This game's challenge (on classic mode, as I recommend everyone to play) will kick you in the teeth, make several cuts on your skin, pour a mix of salt, lemon juice and alcohol on the wounds, all this while waterboarding you. That's how you will suffer everytime if you choose the "classic" mode. But I promise you. If you really enjoy a challenge, like me, you WILL be coming back, again and again and again.

Pros:
-The combat system (You don't just press the "Attack" or "Cast Spell X" button. You have to manage what kind of attack you want, as you always have to risk something);
-The depth of uniqueness to your character.(You have plenty of races, classes, and subclasses that when combined with the randomness of the roguelike genre, make sure that no playthrough is the same.)
-The story(Nosense zone of comedy, funny or not funny, it depends on if you want to "play along" BUT there are some clever twists on the choices that the player has to make (more about it below)).
-The various game systems (You have the typical quests, crafting, and the almost obligatory grinding (if you want to play safe), but then there are arenas and portals where you can risk everything if you want the best weapon drops, panflet reading(where you are presented with a moraly ambiguous subject, and by deciding wherever you agree with it or not, has an impact on your characters ideology, and possibly, the story), Tavern Management(pretty self explanatory), and I don't think i have named everything).
-Amazing soundtrack (Chiptunes with some nice twists on them) and overall sound design(The effects fit very well.)

Cons:
-There are "Events" where you must make decisions, but the outcomes are just random.
-The learning curve is not that bad, the problem is the amounts of reading you have to endure, but then again, it's the game's style.

I strongly recommend this game for the people out there that don't give a flying duck about greyphix and all that other lame stuff that people think that gaming is about today, the entire game is beautifully made in ASCII art. This game has excellent design and lots of nice easter eggs and references and I hope the developer puts more of them in the game considering it's still on Early Access. 

The gameplay is extremely simplistic, you'll choose one of the available options and type it in the prompt and hit enter, then pretty stuff will happen. But don't let simplicity fool you, for this game is rich and has tons of nice  features for you to tinker with, like crafiting and salvaging, bartending and mining, and a well-made battle system with a lot of possibilities to influence the outcome of the battle.

You can choose the appearance of character, gender (3 options, for some it's important so hooray to the developers), name, class, race and then the adventure will begin. But considering it is a roguelike game (there is an option to play without permadeath) I wouldn't get too attached to my carefully created character. But fear not, for after you die a horrible death you can always create another and you'll be wiser and that's the beauty of the roguelikes.

I didn't play it that much yet, but I can assure you that if you like games that have a spoon of funny, ASCII art, RPG mechanics, crafting mechanics all bundled up in a nice simple package that you can play basically on any computer, then you'll have invested your hard earned money in a real work of art. 13462193.review:
Edit: I should mention that this game has distracted me from the Winter Sale entirely.

Ignore the short amount of time that you see on my profile for this game-- what it doesn't tell you is that I've played at least thirty hours of the original form. It only took me a few minutes to really notice a lot of the new changes in the game for the Black Edition, and thus far nothing I've seen has displeased me. Sanctuary is a game that pays devoted respect to the sprawling text-based adventures of old, but has the personality and depth of modern RPGs, with wonderfully humorous writing and lots of tiny references that make old-school gamers smile.

Granted, the game isn't going to be for everyone-- not everyone is going to be thrilled with the difficulty level (this game does not hold your hand), and many will be put off by the text-only controls. For those who prefer something of the old flavor, however, they'll find hours and hours of joy in this game, with its gear crafting, development, combat depth, character customization, and more.

Absolutely worth the price-- and the active role that the developers play in the further growth of the game is evident. They clearly care about this project and love it, and that's something you don't see in gaming as often as one should.

Absolutely fantastic.

13435295.review:
Do you like rogue likes and text based graphics?

This is Sanctuary RPG and as you can see by the graphic above, it is not your typical rogue like or your typical text based adventure. This indie game is being (yes, it is still undergoing further development though it is essentially done) developed by a group called Black Shell Media. If I could describe this game simply, it is a multiple choice rogue like RPG with text based graphics. To play the game, you basically enter a number or letter corresponding to an action or location. You start as a (class of choice, race of choice) type deal, where each class has their own story beginning with plenty of witty and sometimes not at all subtle humour (the range character's story has something about sticking sharp things in bushes, some dirty humour like that). You then go on your quest which I will talk about later and do all amazing things with lots of jokes, including one about breaking the fourth wall, and progress until you come to your demise where the game will end and you will have to start from scratch. You have two base modes (normal and softcore which you can't die in but have 20% less loot drops). After you complete the game you then get harder game modes with better loot drops. Also there is something in the start screen about a character option which can only be changed from the default (potato) by finding the ultra rare drops of them in the game, so lots of replayability.


Shocker! This isn't going to melt your PC or need a GTX Titan Z to run. The aesthetics are nice and simple, but really suit the game. It has that retro feel of some of the first games, but with more colour and more detail. I admittedly was a bit sceptical when I first saw it because it's not really my kind of thing but after a while it grows on you. It is accompanied by a retro pokemon style background composition, which as far as I'm concerned is just fantastic and fits beautifully with the game.

Story wise, you don't have much to work with. It is basically your typical medieval RPG, a witch called the "Matron" gets a super powerful sword and tries to destroy all life, super good wizard guy tries to stop her, goes missing after a big battle, you have to try and find and kill the matron. The rest of the story is pretty much a comedical combination of comedy and obscure (sometimes not so obscure) references. You also have a variety of features including blacksmith (weapons), crafting, a tavern which you can own, library (read books for free XP), Colosseum (battle things for XP and rewards), temple (burn things for charms) and market. So really there is a lot you can do if you're bored. You can also grind the holy bajesus out of places you've already beat. The story is overall pretty good, nothing new but works with the game and I like it.


This is the combat system for the game. Basically, you use starter moves, then linkers, then finishers to rack of damage, but you also have to heal a lot to (obviously heal) remove debuffs etc. You then have special abilities as well as an ultimate which stacks off your combo. Everything is colour co-ordinated so you know what's going on. I never got to master the combat system of repositioning to dodge and all that so I just spammed the attacks and healed whenever I needed to. This works to an extent, until you die in a ball of fire like I did every time I played. There is a sweet spot to it where, unless the RnG Gods choose it's really not your day, you can play it so you'll never die, which is really the idea. I am not a patient fellow, so I went in full attack mode and it really isn't the best approach. Very fun though.


So overall, this game is actually one of my favourites. When I first saw it on Steam, I didn't think I'd like it. But two hours of grinding, crafting and questing later, I found myself really into it to the point where it was getting harder for me to save and quit. There are a lot of really in-depth things I haven't went into including perks and upgrades, because they are pretty much something every RPG player will be familiar with, nothing new there, but there is an extent of the detail of these that is far beyond anything I've seen, even in the likes of Skyrim. I'm talking 3 pages of talking about a particular class' base perks. Pretty amazing. Want to know one of the best things about this game? Infinite hours of play time for £3.99. That cheap. If you regularly find yourself bored and wanting something rewarding to do, buy this game. There is also a free trail. And if you are a rogue like lover, this is definitely for you. Highly rated in my books.

13426022.review:
I've been playing for a few months now, since before it came to Steam. It felt like a full game then, and the devs have only been adding more features to fully flesh out the game's world. I'm very much impressed.

SanctuaryRPG has a unique battle system -- I've never seen anything like it. It's tense, tactical, and exciting.

The music -- especially the battle tunes (there are several, so you're not hearing the same thing every time you fight) -- is just great videogame music, full of well-developed melodies; synthy bleeps and boops; and low, dirty rumblings. I can't say enough about it, other than you NEED to hear it.

The ASCII art is incredible -- not just the enemies but the landscapes as well. Really does a lot to evoke a sense of place.

The game's also rather funny in a way that's difficult to describe. It's bonkers, but it doesn't beat you over the head with wacky antics or slapstick. The in-battle hints, the dialogue, the random events -- all are just strange enough to make you smile and wonder what's coming next.

SanctuaryRPG is truly one of a kind -- don't miss out on this lovingly crafted little gem.
